title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article:
People need to STOP posting pictures of laptops, phones, talking about motorbikes etc and claiming to be poor. Yes, you might well live in a country where you are paid only a few dollars per day, but how cheap it is to live makes up for this. Whilst this is not good, it is how the economy works.
 
I am not being heartless, I know full well that there are many countries around the world where it is hard to get a job, food or education. But you are on the internet, you are therefore un-poor enough to be wasting your time doing nothing.
 
People always talk about India, Africa, South America etc when t
Continue Reading
People need to STOP posting pictures of laptops, phones, talking about motorbikes etc and claiming to be poor. Yes, you might well live in a country where you are paid only a few dollars per day, but how cheap it is to live makes up for this. Whilst this is not good, it is how the economy works.
 
I am not being heartless, I know full well that there are many countries around the world where it is hard to get a job, food or education. But you are on the internet, you are therefore un-poor enough to be wasting your time doing nothing.
 
People always talk about India, Africa, South America etc when they talk about being poor.
 
Do you realise that in Italy a few years ago they changed the law to say that stealing food is not a crime and shouldn’t be punished if you are doing it because you are hungry - why? Because people were doing it.
 
I am from England. I was in foster care from the age of 10, growing up I met people who slept in the same bed as 4–6 siblings, people who would go out and have to wash cars or do paper rounds so that they could feed themselves. People who, at the age of 13 were sent to prison for theft, burglary or dealing drugs because they required money as they had no other means of getting it. That isn’t mentioning the fact there are families who 
have 
to take their older siblings hand-me-down clothes. Not because they are smaller but because there is no money to pay for anything else.
 
Being poor is completely relative to the situation and place you live in, if you live in London, you cannot live a measly wage, you live in certain parts of the West Midlands, Wales and many other places - you can eat very well buying shopping £20 per week (this is pocket money after having paid bills).
 
The UK is one of the most expensive countries in which to live, because of the fact that we have an awful lot of greedy rich people, we are a small ass island, our currency being worth the most in the world market also means that the business owners are stingy with it. People used to get paid for their skills, nowadays because there are so many people out there looking for jobs, practically every job pays minimum wage. Unless you live in a bedsit - one room with bedroom, kitchen (sometimes shared), bathroom (most of the time shared with two other people) - you cannot live on your own. Basic rent for a house/ flat in my city which is not poor but not great either is around £550 per month, then you have 80-£120 council tax, £30 water, £30 gas, £30 electric (these are estimates). This before you are talking about food, travel expenses, clothing, having children, phones etc.
 
Contrary to popular belief, most people in the so called first world countries are not rich or do not have more money, yes we might have more than others, however most of it is on credit. This means that most people don’t actually own anything that is theirs - 
they may owe thousands for university (and will be paying it for the rest of their lives)
 they owe thousands for their car
 credit cards (a lot of people require this because they cannot pay everything out then survive until the end of the month), they don’t own their homes, the banks do, they are paying the banks back little by little, the average household takes about 50 years for two people to pay it off. 
phone contracts - on credit
 
*Edit: 1 bedroom flats in my city start at £650 (cheap) a single person on the most common wage of minimum wage will only earn about £1020 after tax.

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
If you're trying to be a runner it is.
Even then going to the gym is helpful. Some marathon runners improve their times by training on the treadmill (thus in the gym)
[1]
. Lifting weights is also helpful in improving your core strength, increasing your upper body strength, thus improving the amount of power you can generate with your arms. Naturally, of course, working your lower body can increase the power and speed that your legs will generate.
 
Lest I forget to mention, it's not good to do ANY intense activity day in and out. Rest days are essential.
 
There are tons of 
benefits to running
, especial
Continue Reading
Footnotes
[1] 
How Real Runners Train on Treadmills
If you're trying to be a runner it is.
Even then going to the gym is helpful. Some marathon runners improve their times by training on the treadmill (thus in the gym)
[1]
. Lifting weights is also helpful in improving your core strength, increasing your upper body strength, thus improving the amount of power you can generate with your arms. Naturally, of course, working your lower body can increase the power and speed that your legs will generate.
 
Lest I forget to mention, it's not good to do ANY intense activity day in and out. Rest days are essential.
 
There are tons of 
benefits to running
, especially high to moderate intensity  running. There are also tons of 
benefits to resistance training
.
 
Resistance training can take far less time to get the same benefits as running.
 
Let me lay this out there. Fitness isn't a binary process. There isn't a single best method to get you optimal benefits. Running (or some other form of moderate to high intensity cardio) AND hitting the gym is the best under all circumstances.  The proportions of how you do them and what how you particularly approach each activity depends on your goals.
Footnotes
[1] 
How Real Runners Train on Treadmills

Continue Reading
OK. Let’s tell a story about a kid out of Hamilton, IN. I was going back to school for a Pre-med classes (requirements for an M.S. nurse practitioner degree) and living in Fort Wayne, IN at the time. The class was a history class (My B.S. apparently was short one social studies credit). The class was at a community college (they had a pretty good R.N. program there). We had this one boy who showed up to about every third class from up north in one of the more rural counties (Hamilton) that one day out of the blue( he often spent the minutes before class striking up conversations with the girls in the class) decided to brag about his busy weekend to try to impress the girls. As I sat down in front of him, he started out:
 
him: You guys want to hear a great story about this weekend?
 
Nobody is really paying attention at this point as he was broadcasting in general and not to anyone specific.
 
him: It was a good day Saturday. I got me a cat.
 
One of the girls perked up at that point: Oh yeah, what kind of cat?
 
him: A grey cat with a white spot on his chest. I think one of his feet was white.
 
Girl: Ohhh, cute. Is he Spayed or Neutered?
 
him: No. Sort of.
 
Other girl chiming in: You should get the cat spayed or neutered, can’t remember which.
 
Other girl 2 chiming in: Yeah, it’s neutered. You should get it neutered.
 
him: Oh? I guess you could say he’s neutered or spayed. I saw him in the back out by the garage and I went and got my pistol. Right between the eyes. Clean shot.
 
Girls in unison: Ewww.
 
Me: Really? What caliber, a .45?
 
him: Naw, a .45 would have messed him up, I thought about grabbing the rifle, but probably would have gone clean through. I used a .22.
 
him (trying to recapture the attention of the female crowd who turned away): Funny thing about it. I called the Chinese restaurant and they didn’t want the cat.
 
Me: That’s because you ruined the best part of the cat, the brain.
 
He could clearly see that I am Chinese and sitting one chair away, never heard the sarcasm or understood that he was being racist ass, but this was common in Indiana.

TWO

[me] “I’d like the BLT on a sub roll please”
 
[him, as he was cutting the roll] “would you like lettuce and tomato?”
 
I just couldn’t help myself as I responded “well if I didn’t wouldn’t this just be a ‘B’?”
 
I watched his face as the realization of his question and my response reached his brain

article:
“Poor” is a very relative term. Unless of course, you define it yourself.
 
Any one earning any less than $60 a month, is qualified to be classified as a “poor” person, one, particularly, UNDER the Below Poverty Line (BPL) classification.
 
Lets begin with my background. No, I am not poor, not as described by the government. I was 
extremely lucky 
to have been born into this house hold, wherein, my father is a very renowned professor and researcher, and my mother is a school teacher, and also a researcher at an University. We have a total income of about 2300$ every month, and that is WAY more than e
Continue Reading
“Poor” is a very relative term. Unless of course, you define it yourself.
 
Any one earning any less than $60 a month, is qualified to be classified as a “poor” person, one, particularly, UNDER the Below Poverty Line (BPL) classification.
 
Lets begin with my background. No, I am not poor, not as described by the government. I was 
extremely lucky 
to have been born into this house hold, wherein, my father is a very renowned professor and researcher, and my mother is a school teacher, and also a researcher at an University. We have a total income of about 2300$ every month, and that is WAY more than enough for all the luxuries one can think of in a span of 3 seconds.
 
We have a car, a 2 BHK flat, 2 inherited bungalows, and a rich heritage. I know, for a fact, that both my parents had to face very hard days, in his childhood, but I don’t have to, thanks to their sincerity in attaining education.
 
Oh, and I study in THE most premiere, and oldest school of my nation.
 
Then, what do I lack? Why am I even answering this question on Quora?
 
The answer, lies in my first sentence. I feel poor everyday. Why? Because, in the school I attend, all students are from extremely wealthy families, with an estimated average income of about $15,500. Pretty much everyone has at least 2 cars, with a chauffeur at their command at all times. They go for expensive dinners and trips. They all have iPhones, Gucci and Versace threads, expensive suits, and a lot of admirers.
 
On the other hand, I travel by public transport. My family has ONE car. I don’t have expensive watches, nor phones (not that I need them). Only the usual ones. I have common clothes (not cheapskate, but just 
normal
). We dine out at normal restaurants, and I have never been abroad. Only domestic.
 
Spending hours with these kind of people from societies that I don’t belong to, had been a very sad part of my life. I did not want to attend school anymore. I didn’t want to use public transport anymore. I was tired, sick of my life. The poor kid sleeping on the road would be jealous of my life, but I was sick of it.
 
Then, I thought about it, I thought how hard my parents work, just for my benefit. I thought, that I must give my parents, what I desire. Not expect them to give it to me. And here I am today, renowned all over my school, as THE artist, THE physicist, THE swimmer, and THE debator.
 
Yes, it was my self confidence, that helped me change myself. I am proud of my parents, and forever shall be. Thanks, mom and dad.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Maybe not the most ignorant…. But still a funny story. I was tutoring a group of 8th graders before the end of year tests. One of my students asked why we were off for “Milk Day" every year. I must have appeared confused because she repeated herself.
 
I finally understood her and asked, “Do you mean the MLK observance day? Like Martin Luther King, Jr?”
 
Her reply, “He was a real person?”
 
I just put my head in my hands and sighed.

So I'm walking home Friday from the library and I see an elderly woman trying to get down stairs, carrying groceries.
 
I offer her my arm and to carry the groceries for her. She thanks me and I tell her she reminds me of my grandmother, who was also fiercely independent. I miss Savta, she was not a kind lady, but she was very inspiring.
 
"Well, you'll see her in heaven," she says.
 
I say nothing.
 
"You do believe in heaven, right?" she asks.
 
I tell her no, I'm secular.
 
She proceeds with a rant about how secular people have no morality and don't even know the bible. "Were you even taught the Ten Commandments?" she asked in a superior tone.
 
"In two languages, including the original," I inform her. "I was raised Jewish." I can rattle them off in full on demand in Hebrew and English.
 
"Jewish people killed Jesus," she said as we arrive to her car. "That's why God punished them with a Holocaust." I’m carrying her groceries with one hand and helping her down the street.
 
I am proud to say I didn't ‘accidentally’ drop her groceries. I'm very proud of myself for not losing my temper.
 
I did leave her groceries by the car and say "Well, I hope you get home safely," I said, shaking with rage and walking away.
 
My grandmother survived Auschwitz.

Poor is relative. I am poor by my country’s standards and what I was used to. I am disabled and rely on benefits (after having worked all of my adult life as well as raising a family), I cannot afford luxuries, I often have to choose between paying a bill or buying decent food. Right now I can’t afford the internet (it’s not amazingly cheap), luckily my neighbour is happy to let me use his internet otherwise I wouldn't be on Quora answering this question. I never buy new clothes, they’re either given to me by family and friends or they come from charity shops. My diet is mostly cheap food, I bulk up on rice, lentils and pasta, while not unhealthy there isn’t much variety and its’ very boring. I don’t have a social life, partly due t my disability and partly due to not being able to afford one. I live in a tiny house which is in the middle of a slum area because I can’t afford anything else.
But…..if I compare my situation to some of the people who have answered then I am quite wealthy, or to many other people around the world. I do know that I will always have something to eat, I have the ability to heat my house and eat hot food. I have clothes, a bed and shoes, so while for a 1st world country I am poor compare that to many other countries and I am rich.

I’m Canadian and work as a consultant, usually for large Financial Institutions. In 2006–2007 I got hired by a a very well known invetment bank in New York City. Now this bank is the cream of the crop, extremely profitable, aggressive, well connected and they can and do hire only the very best & brightest or so I thought.
 
Now, remember, I’m Canadian and we’re usually pretty easy going, polite and genuinely nice people as a whole. So what happened on our first team lunch in the Financial District, where I met the team I’d be working with really taxed my self control. I was introduced and I mentioned that I’d just moved to NYC from Toronto where I’d pretty much grown up.
 
“Is it true that some of you still live in igloos?”
 was one of the dumbest questions I was asked that afternoon. I had no choice but to reply 
“Yeah, but we’re lucky, we’ve got hot & cold running water in ours…”
 and my colleague accepted it, with a look of sympathy on his face!
 
I was asked if we all 
“voted for the Queen?”
 and obviously I had to give the correct answer, 
“No, we’re thinking of following your lead and having our own Tea Party but in Halifax, got any pointers?”
 
Apparently my colleagues were also quite happy that we didn’t have major issues with Moose roaming our cities. Their concern was touching.
 
And when I related the old Inuit 
(these are the Native Canadians who live in the Arctic)
 practice of their elderly walking out onto an ice floe to die so they wouldn’t be a burden on their families 
(this is true, they really did that 100+ years ago)
, I got sombre nods in return and I’m sure a few thought I was planning my own parent’s final walk on the ice someday.
 
Now these were smart, well educated young people. Schools like Harvard, Wharton and so on. Not everyone at the table of about 20 asked these questions and I know not everybody accepted my answers but SOME OF THEM DID.
 
That’s when I came to the conclusion that these weren’t “Masters of the Universe…”, they were bright, good at their jobs but a few were dumber than a bag of rocks.

Dear Onur Ceylan [ https://www.quora.com/profile/Onur-Ceylan-1 ]:
 
If you are new to weightlifting and powerlifting, I suggest looking for a plan tailored to your current fitness. I recommend working with a coach to determine the required hours based on your fitness and goals. For general purpose knowledge, I can share my experience.
 
 
The frequency of training directly impacts your progress with whatever goals you may have the desire to achieve.
 
I focus on total fitness, strength/power training and I also focus on mobility, flexibility, and cardiovascular conditioning. I train 2-4 times every ten days on non-consecutive days when I follow a specific cycle of training.
 
Since I hardly ever train with body part isolation and split routines, I follow my plan practicing with the big five exercises on different days, but I also slide in the Olympic lifts with light weights each time I train.
 
This sort of training will produce a lean athletic body with terrific mobility and heart and lungs conditioning. It agrees with my standards of fitness.
 
For the new trainers, in time you can build a fantastic fitness with only three sessions of full body workouts (weekly). The rest of the week you must focus on proper diet/nutrition (quality and quantity of food), good physical rest and recovery. You must also think through your current training program and start making progress with volume, intensity, frequency and personal records. An ex...

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Muscles and your nervous system need to recover from the exercise stress. You don't grow from exercising. You grow from proper rest after properly performed exercises.
 
Fitness beginners require more rest between exercises than people who are at an intermediate to advanced level.
 
Body types also vary. Some respond and grow more quickly than others.
 
If you do full body workouts every day you won't gain as much lean muscle mass as you would if you did it two, three, or four times per week. And you'll be at a greater risk for injuries, which can stop exercises for days, weeks or months of recovery.
 
I 
Continue Reading

I understand the addiction and I love to exercise upper and lower body everyday. I just vary which areas I work and keep the total volume (time under tension/sets and reps) lower each day.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
It’s 2012, a month before the presidential election. I’m finishing a meeting and we start talking about politics a bit. It’s Obama vs. Romney and his binders of women. “Nobody puts baby in a binder”, I say and we’re laughing.
 
Except one man. He’s in his 50’s (and so was I) and he’s white. As I’m walking out, he walks next to me and starts to speak to me. Loudly.
 
He “schools” me-If I know what’s good for me and my country, I’ll vote for Romney. That Kenyan Muslim, Obama, is going to rape (his word) this nation. He only wants to be re-elected to finish what he’s started!
 
I can only say, “Excuse me?
Continue Reading
It’s 2012, a month before the presidential election. I’m finishing a meeting and we start talking about politics a bit. It’s Obama vs. Romney and his binders of women. “Nobody puts baby in a binder”, I say and we’re laughing.
 
Except one man. He’s in his 50’s (and so was I) and he’s white. As I’m walking out, he walks next to me and starts to speak to me. Loudly.
 
He “schools” me-If I know what’s good for me and my country, I’ll vote for Romney. That Kenyan Muslim, Obama, is going to rape (his word) this nation. He only wants to be re-elected to finish what he’s started!
 
I can only say, “Excuse me?”
 
And then the fun REALLY begins.. “Women need to get it through their heads that they have a place and it’s time they figured that out again. Women belong at home, not in the office and women today think they have a “right” to take all the jobs just because we “got the vote.”
 
Are you freaking KIDDING me?
 
And so I say to him, “Let me get this straight-you are suggesting I exercise my right to vote in such a way as to lose other rights?”
 
“Don’t you get it?”, he sneers, “You’re one of those stupid liberal women who think abortion is OK. Everyone knows it’s only LIBERAL women who get abortions because the conservative women are God-fearing, good women who know better than to have sex before marriage. Why, you liberals use abortion as a form of birth control and it’s time the US became a Christian nation once again and the only way to do that is to vote for Romney! There’s nothing better for America than women being back in the kitchen, barefoot and pregnant.” The man is so close, he’s spitting in my face. The more I step back, the more he steps towards me.
 
STUPID doesn’t begin to cover it.
 
I looked at him and told him he was dumb as F**k and he needed to educate himself. And that sent him into spasms all over again.
 
How dare I speak to him that way? How dare I use that word? Who did I think I was? This man was like acting like a demon possessed.
 
And so, I said it again. I couldn’t help it; I started to laugh. And I laughed and laughed and laughed. I told him to step back and to stay away as I walked to my car. And I just kept on laughing. The entire episode was ludicrous.
 
I had talked with plenty of conservatives during that time and while they were passionate, they weren’t like THIS. I knew within seconds this wasn’t a person I could have a meaningful conversation with. Nor did I even want to.
 
This was the first time I was fully confronted with people who live in this alternate reality and it showed me just how bad they really are. It’s scary to think this kind of thinking actually exists in our society. But it does and to make sure the rest of us know it, they voted for Trump.

I spend more money each month on insulin and special food for my two cats that were dumped when others had enough of them then my husband and I spend on our own food. I rescue other abandoned animals, help rehabilitate and rehome them, I bake for my neighbours, I teach English to those who need help, and I never buy fast food and coffees at outside places. I still wear a pair of jeans that I have owned for 23 years and keep patching, I have no problem wearing others castoffs, yet I consider myself incredibly rich in love from animals and humans.
 
Money may be nice, but sharing what you have is much nicer in my opinion.

Intense exercises (e.g., jumping jacks) with short rest. Aim for 20-30 minutes.
Yoga: 
Boost flexibility and mental well-being. Various levels available online.

Bodyweight Circuit:

For added accountability and motivation, check out Fitneks, a live video fitness platform connecting you to trainers and communities. Stay consistent, adjust intensity as needed, and consult professionals for personalized advice, especially if you have existing health conditions. All the best on your fitness journey!

Over 20 years ago, I was in Tennessee for business and, after a long hard day, decided to go for a walk. After about 20 minutes I came across a shop that sold beer. I found myself a single can, chosen for the refreshment rather than the alcohol content. I was asked for ID. (I was 30!) Fortunately, I had my passport on me. The shop owner took one look at it and said that they didn't accept that as it was not an American passport. Rather taken aback by this, I showed him my driving licence. Again, not US ID, so not acceptable. He then, appearing exasperated, asked me whether I had American ID or not. To which my reply was "With a UK passport and driving licence, I am obviously british, so will be unlikely to hold US ID", at which he produced a gun and told me to leave in 10 seconds, as he hated being spoken to like that. The ironic thing is that ahead of me in the queue was a young lad of 13 - 14 years, buying bullets for his gun needing to show NO ID at all!
 
Needless to say, when I told my business clients this story over dinner, they asked me what I expected? Not that at all.
 
I must say though, that having been to the states a number of times on business and holiday, Americans have been quite welcoming. Mind you, I normally go to New York and the New England area

title: How to workout
article:
I start my day by doing some animal flow. Animal Flow is ground-based movement, made fun, challenging and effective.
 
It is a structured series of animal-style movements that can be linked together to form flows (similar to yoga). It's good for building mobility, strength and developing motor control (something many programs are missing).
 
What is Animal Flow?
 
Created by Mike Fitch, Animal Flow is a trademarked bodyweight program that’s centred largely around ground-based work. It features animal-style movements that encourage core stability and strength, joint strength, and body awareness — all wi
Continue Reading
I start my day by doing some animal flow. Animal Flow is ground-based movement, made fun, challenging and effective.
 
It is a structured series of animal-style movements that can be linked together to form flows (similar to yoga). It's good for building mobility, strength and developing motor control (something many programs are missing).
 
What is Animal Flow?
 
Created by Mike Fitch, Animal Flow is a trademarked bodyweight program that’s centred largely around ground-based work. It features animal-style movements that encourage core stability and strength, joint strength, and body awareness — all without any fitness equipment.
 
If yoga and Capoeira(a system of physical discipline and movement originating among Brazilian slaves, treated as a martial art and dance form) were to have a baby, it would look like animal flow. The idea behind animal flow is it develops mobility as well as power. This system is also designed to improve strength, power, flexibility, mobility, and coordination for all levels of fitness enthusiasts.
 
So, should you try it?
 
Sure, it’s a little bit intimidating at first, but it’s a cool and unique way of moving your body and it’s a really good workout.
 
For those still wary to try “just have fun and let go of any inhibitions you might have.”
 
It feels silly at the beginning, but everyone’s there for the same purpose.

This didn’t happen to me, and it didn’t happen in the US, but it does fit in well with the “ignorant American” theme.
 
I’m South African, my dad was in high school in the 70’s, and one of the families at his school hosted an American girl as an exchange student for the year. Now in South Africa the school year runs from January to December, meaning that our long holiday coincides with Christmas and the southern hemisphere summer. This family arrived at the airport in Durban to pick the girl up, and saw her dressed in thick winter clothes. After greeting her, they asked if she wanted to go to the bathroom and change into some cooler clothes for the drive back home. She looked around all confused and said, “But I don’t understand! It’s summer in America!”
 
It must be said though that America definitely doesn’t have the monopoly on ignorant people. Our own president believed that Africa was the biggest continent in the world and wasn’t crossed by any rivers. He also doesn’t seem to be able to do basic maths…

title: How workout exercises?
article:
In old school body building routines they used basic movements, nothing fancy. Reg Park's 5x5 routine was literally just back squat, deadlift, and bench press and variations of the theme.
 
It's a myth that people get strong and gain muscle by doing lots of exercises. You need to force your muscles to grow: lift big, heavy weights, in basic movements, and get a nice pump.
 
If you're just starting out, then doing close push-ups and weighted push-ups might help you gain a little muscle, but eventually you'll have to do heavy movements like presses, deadlifts, and squats.. 
 
If you are just starting out
Continue Reading
In old school body building routines they used basic movements, nothing fancy. Reg Park's 5x5 routine was literally just back squat, deadlift, and bench press and variations of the theme.
 
It's a myth that people get strong and gain muscle by doing lots of exercises. You need to force your muscles to grow: lift big, heavy weights, in basic movements, and get a nice pump.
 
If you're just starting out, then doing close push-ups and weighted push-ups might help you gain a little muscle, but eventually you'll have to do heavy movements like presses, deadlifts, and squats.. 
 
If you are just starting out, I suggest you stick to 2-3 compound exercises per workout. rotate between the basics: squat (back or front), deadlift, cleans (if you can do them), a press (overhead, bench, dips), rows. Do pull-ups and some kind of ab work like hanging leg raises or vacuums ever day.
 
Doing few exercises and working really hard on them will give you far better results than doing 3 exercises per muscle group
 
It is possible to overwork a muscle group, but over training is over-worried-about. I work out my back, grip, and legs every single day. Your body will adapt to whatever you throw at it as long as you sleep, and eat well. 
 
Good luck!
 
Nate

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Not a person, but a whole region.
 
After moving to Bumfuck, KY I have met many, many people who I would call ignorant. I really think they've only seen brown people on tv.
 
Talking to some girl at the gym:
 
Me: Yea I just moved here from Maryland.
 
Her: Oh, is that over there by Afghanistan?
 
Me: ……no
 
The demographics of the county I work in is 96% white and the rest are mostly black. I'm from Pakistan and I obviously look like it as well. I get looks from people all the time because I stick out very easily.
 
I'm not Muslim (I love me some ribs, mmm), I was born in the US and I only know how to speak Engli

Not a person, but a whole region.
 
After moving to Bumfuck, KY I have met many, many people who I would call ignorant. I really think they've only seen brown people on tv.
 
Talking to some girl at the gym:
 
Me: Yea I just moved here from Maryland.
 
Her: Oh, is that over there by Afghanistan?
 
Me: ……no
 
The demographics of the county I work in is 96% white and the rest are mostly black. I'm from Pakistan and I obviously look like it as well. I get looks from people all the time because I stick out very easily.
 
I'm not Muslim (I love me some ribs, mmm), I was born in the US and I only know how to speak English (typical American). First day on the job and I’m going around to check out the plant and meet some people.
 
Me: Hey nice to meet you, my name is Mustafa.
 
Him: Oh, are you from Iraq?
 
Me: ……no
 
There was also a time where a pulled pork sandwich saved me from landing on the employee enforced terrorist watch list.
We were having a party at the plant for no LTI’s ( Lost Time Incidents) for like the last year. They catered BBQ and there was a whole spread of pulled pork, cole slaw, corn, potato salad, etc.
 
Free food? Shit, first thing I did was throw my lunch away. That BBQ was so fucking good. I ate 3 plates and sampled everything. We didn't have BBQ like this back in Maryland (or should I say Iraq, lol). It was a good thing I ate everything too.
 
I was later told that apparently some people were watching me to see if I ate the pork or not. Based on that data and knowing me for 5 months, they would conclude whether I was a potential terrorist threat or not...
 
I sincerely pity the people who have this way of thinking.
 
Edit: I think I was re-living the frustration of these events as I was writing this answer. I did not intend for this answer to be so negative. Although I bashed some of the people around here for some of their actions, there are many more people who are absurdly polite and generous. You can pretty much strike up a conversation with anyone around here too. Like I said, I pity some of the people around here because I believe the history and demographics of this area inhibit tolerance.
 
Edit 2: Anonymous because I still work for this company. I googled my name and this answer was right next to it. I don't want HR to make a big deal out of this, so keep it on the down low.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
You can do a full-body workout two days in a row once your body has grown accustomed to it. Train on alternating days at first to build up your stamina and improve your tolerance for heavy workouts. Stick to a routine, and you should be able to work up to full-body exercises on back-to-back days.
 
While a full-body workout training split has its advantages, it's best not to do it every day. It's important that your muscles have adequate rest and recovery time to prevent overtraining. So, if you prefer a full-body workout training split, keep it to 2-3 workouts per week for the best results.

ne particular afternoon, soon after she arrived.
 
She was having lunch with some of her new friends and they were introducing themselves, saying where they were from, and so on. When she said she was from South Africa, the Americans in the group said,
 
“Oh, you’re from Africa! Then you must be 
black!”
 
She told me that she looked at her arm in astonishment, and said, “No, I’m not black.”
 
They replied, “Oh, no, if you’re from Africa, you must be black!”

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article:
Peppered Pastrami.
I don’t mean the MEGA pastrami sandwiches I see on American youtube videos like this
Years and years ago near the 6th form college I went to, there was a small Italian bistro. They did £1.20 pastrami sandwiches, which was actually quite expensive in the 1990s. They’d stick it in hot water to heat it up a little and it would be put in a bread roll.
 
The 10 minute breaks between lectures meant there was enough time to go out cross the road and get a sandwich.
 
I never tasted anything that tasted quite like these sandwiches 25 years later :/

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I am an American, and the list of ignorant people is long … as most of these answers seem to deal with traveling, I will add to this theme.
 
I lived in New Mexico. Yes, Karen, it is in the USA. I moved to Hawaii. Again, yes, a bona-fide US state.
 
I lived in Belgium and Germany and went on a lot of trips with local friends. The rudest people I came across were a trio from Canada! Loud, crass, atrocious manners - I was shocked!
 
As a whole though, both British and German holidaymakers were quite boorish.
 
Ignorance is not restricted to one group.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: I was in college when a girl in one of my classes and I got to talking and became casual friends. One day she told me she had started talking to some guy she had seen in a bus station. She actually gave him my phone number and my address at college. I went off on her, telling her she had a s—load of nerve peddling my personal information, didn’t she have the brains to know she put me in a situation that could be dangerous for me, and on and on. She said, “I’ve done this for other people and they never got mad like you.” Wow. Brainless, ignorant, I could go on.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: I came to the US in february for the very first time and was slightly nervous about the travel ban. It didn't affect me but I was just afraid of TSA shenanigans. After passing immigration, I was waiting for boarding the next flight when I had some small talk with a young lady next to me. After I told her I was from Germany, she asked “That's where the Nazis rule, right?”. She honestly thought Hitler was still in power. I've only been speechless a couple of times in my whole life and this was one of them. I don't know how long it took me to close my kouth again…

Continue Reading
Make a Workout Schedule:
Both resistance training and cardiovascular exercise are needed in my opinion.
 
Cardio such as walking, running, and spinning burns calories and helps in the maintenance of proper heart functioning. However, resistance training which is often overlooked is equally needed for the maintenance of a healthy weight. As you age, the body’s bone density and muscle mass deplete. To maintain proper metabolic function, weight training is imperative! Building strong muscles means burning more calories at rest, ultimately resulting in a healthier body weight. For beginners, I recommend at least 2 days of weight training a week along with at least 3 days of cardiovascular exercise. While this may seem like too much time, you can combine the two activities! Moves like jump squats and burpee’s get your heart rate up and your muscles burning!
 
2. Change up your routine:
 
Fitness does not have to be boring! Keeping fitness fun will not only improve your adherence to exercise, but it is actually proven that changing the FITT (frequency, intensity, time, and type) of your exercise routine will yield better results. For fun workouts ideas check out my Instagram page 
@bodyby.becca.
 
3. The ’80-20’ rule- Flexibility is Key
 
The ‘All or Nothing’ mindset is inherently destructive. You don’t need a 1 hour workout or a perfect day of clean eating for it to “count.” No one is perfect and your healthy routine won’t be either! I use the ’80-20’ rule when discussing healthy lifestyle habits with clients. Meaning, 80% of the time you make consciously healthy decisions (intuitive eating and exercise) while 20% of the time strict adherence is not necessary. Just as one good meal won’t make you healthy, one missed workout wont make you unhealthy! I have found this strategy to be attainable for both myself and clients; in turn, resulting in the greatest rate of long term success. Eat the ice cream once and a while, it won’t kill you. Mental health is just as important as your physical health!
 
4. Macronutrient Essentials:
 
No, you don’t need to count calories or macronutrients, but awareness of what is going into your body is key. In order to look and FEEL your best, the body requires all three macronutrients: carbohydrates, protein and fat. Try to include all three categories every time you sit down for a meal. If you miss one during one meal, make up for it the next! Again, flexibility is key.
 
Examples of carbohydrates include: vegetables, grains, fruits.
 
Examples of protein include: chicken, salmon, quinoa, beans.
 
Examples of fat include: avocado, nuts, olive oil.
 
*** Note that the caloric value of fats is necessary but DOES add up fast, so I recommend measuring out these foods before consumption.
 
5. Drink Water:
 
Tip: drink a full glass of water before every meal to help curb your appetite.
 
The benefits of water consumption cannot be reiterated enough! Drinking water promotes weight loss by removing the by products of fat from the body. On top of that, it fills your stomach, helping you differentiate between real hunger and thirst, which your body can misinterpret as hunger.
 
6. Take a well rounded approach to fitness:
 
The benefits of eating well and adopting healthy lifestyle habits go far beyond the physical. The mental changes you experience are immeasurable. Of course, the specifics vary depending on the person. From my experience, I have less self doubt and stress, along with more energy, confidence, and happiness since adopting a healthy lifestyle. Unknowingly, these benefits manifest much more quickly than the physical goal and seep into all facets of your life: relationships, work or school, and social life. Being consciously aware of these changes will help you appreciate this amazing journey and the progress you have made so far.

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
Depends entirely on your goals and what “full-body workout” means to you. If your goal is to develop endurance and be able to have functional strength that you can call on any time, then training every day might not just be desirable, it may be necessary. If your goal is to build maximal strength or to build muscle via hypertrophy, then training every day may well work against you, as those gains happen when you give yourself time to recover from training.
 
For some people, volume and frequency need to be managed. Some people can get away with a lot of it, frequently, others need to have a good 
Continue Reading
Depends entirely on your goals and what “full-body workout” means to you. If your goal is to develop endurance and be able to have functional strength that you can call on any time, then training every day might not just be desirable, it may be necessary. If your goal is to build maximal strength or to build muscle via hypertrophy, then training every day may well work against you, as those gains happen when you give yourself time to recover from training.
 
For some people, volume and frequency need to be managed. Some people can get away with a lot of it, frequently, others need to have a good gap in their workouts with maximum recovery time. Genetics plays a part in this.

Such a big question. Wow. I would include cardio here. My go to is always running but yours can be anything that gets your heart pumping. I especially enjoy doing sprints. I like the challenge of jumping rope for ten minutes. It’s more challenging than it sounds. I suggest working out at least 4–5 days a week. Our bodies get used to it and function best that way. I try to pull in my abs even when I’m not working them out. An easy example is to press your back into the back of your carseat while driving to engage your abs. Boot Camp classes focus on different muscles groups on different days. One day might be abs and arms, another legs and booty. I like mixing things up so I don’t get bored. Using your own body as resistance can be fun, too. I do squats while I brush my teeth. I work out at home with weights, bands, a Bosu, a trampoline, an old school Spin bike. A lot of my friends like group classes on a Peloton. Others prefer Yoga or Pilates. Have you ever checked out big wave surfer Laird Hamilton’s XPT work-outs? He’s a big advocate of ice baths and at his work-out seminars in Malibu and Hawaii he has participants walk under water in his pool carrying weights. 82 year old actor James Brolin swears by this for keeping him youthful. The choices are endless, your routine is up to you.

article:

Begin by doing just 5 pushups a day. If you can’t do pushups, do a plank for 10–30 seconds, depending on your starting strength.
 
Then, when you feel unchallenged by this, do 5 pushups/10 -30 sec plank and 5 squat jumps or maybe 10 pushups/30–60 sec plank.
 
Then, start incorporating other exercises in small increments and/or increase the repetitions of your current exercises.
 
Start holding weights while you do squats and lunges. Learn how to do more dynamic plank exercises.

Continue Reading
Start small!
 
Begin by doing just 5 pushups a day. If you can’t do pushups, do a plank for 10–30 seconds, depending on your starting strength.
 
Then, when you feel unchallenged by this, do 5 pushups/10 -30 sec plank and 5 squat jumps or maybe 10 pushups/30–60 sec plank.
 
Then, start incorporating other exercises in small increments and/or increase the repetitions of your current exercises.
 
Start holding weights while you do squats and lunges. Learn how to do more dynamic plank exercises.
 
Do this over many months and keeping working towards heavier weights or more reps (don’t overdo the reps though - that can lead to repetitive strain injuries).
 
If you feel tired one day, just do 5 pushups or a plank or whatever you started at. By giving yourself an opportunity to ease into it on your tired days, you may surprise yourself by pushing a little farther just because you feel warmed up and motivated by your resolve. Give yourself opportunities to succeed and exceed your own expectations!
 
That’s how you can exercise every day, without fail. Keep building out and switching up your workouts and, even if you are injured, you will have something you can do every single day, even if only for a minute or two with your own body weight.

Maybe not the most ignorant, but definitely the most annoying American I’ve met.
 
He was an exchange student in Poland. Naturally he got lots of attention here because I think many Europeans find Americans amusing. One evening we were chatting outside the restaurant where all exchange students had a nice welcome dinner. I was in a group of three friends, I am from Nepal, one friend was from Italy and the other one was Portuguese with a Venezuelan mother.
 
The American started chatting with us, and I didn’t say anything because I just found him irritating but was listening to the conversation that unfolded. In a while came the topic of Venezuela, which my Portuguese friend is actually quite proud to be associated with. The American guy said something like, “Venezuela? Come on, nobody cares about Venezuela. What’s the GDP of Venezuela?” and made snide remarks on how Venezuela was basically a backwater country.
 
I found him even more annoying after then. I really do not understand why he got so much attention.
 
Most Americans I’ve met abroad (in Europe) have been incredibly boastful of their country and just loud and annoying. I will have to go to the US one day to meet some down-to-earth Americans I guess.

article:

But in the 1970’s, when I was a teen, explicit language was very much an exception in the pop music I knew. The success of a record was very much, at that time, long before the “wild wild west” of the Internet, connected to the AM and FM radio airplay it got, and strict FCC censorship laws applied to song lyrics at that time. Most sexual (and illicit drug or government protest) references had to be cloaked in metaphor… intimated in one w
Continue Reading
Nowadays, many songs are explicit… played in a variety of contexts without a whisper of protest. Do CD’s even have to display an Adult Content warning anymore?
 
But in the 1970’s, when I was a teen, explicit language was very much an exception in the pop music I knew. The success of a record was very much, at that time, long before the “wild wild west” of the Internet, connected to the AM and FM radio airplay it got, and strict FCC censorship laws applied to song lyrics at that time. Most sexual (and illicit drug or government protest) references had to be cloaked in metaphor… intimated in one way of another, not explicitly stated. Another trick at that time was to have the lead singer mutter and garble any words that might be objectionable.
 
So you can imagine how startled I was, attending a party in 1980, to hear the DJ suddenly put THIS record on. It was the dirtiest song lyric I had ever heard up until that time.
 
But it was— and still is— an incredible sounding record, and I remember going out to purchase that album the day after the party.

After all, what we see in result (number of views/upvotes etc…) is : “So many people around are suffering from the same wrong perspective”…
 
and is that why they wanted to check the answer? or upvoted this?
 
NB: I also upvoted this…

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

I had a letter to mail to Bozeman, MT. A young undergrad student was at the counter. I gave her this letter to weigh out and to calculate the postage amount due. She looked at the address on the letter and returned it to me saying you can't mail letters abroad from here! I found it hard to keep a straight face and had to educate her about the letter being sent to a domestic destination.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
Studies show that exercising later in the day is much more beneficial than working out in the morning, as your bodily functions are at their best at this time so you’ll have more energy and more strength for an optimal workout. However, many find it harder to exercise after a long day at work.
 
“You’ll likely have more energy to exercise in the second half of the day, compared to the first thing in the morning.”
Your body temperature is highest in the evening. Muscles and joints are up to 20% more flexible this time compared to in the morning, which makes it easier and less of a strain to exercis
Continue Reading
Studies show that exercising later in the day is much more beneficial than working out in the morning, as your bodily functions are at their best at this time so you’ll have more energy and more strength for an optimal workout. However, many find it harder to exercise after a long day at work.
 
“You’ll likely have more energy to exercise in the second half of the day, compared to the first thing in the morning.”
Your body temperature is highest in the evening. Muscles and joints are up to 20% more flexible this time compared to in the morning, which makes it easier and less of a strain to exercise. Chances of injuries during exercise is also lower than morning workouts.
You’ll likely have more energy to exercise in the second half of the day, compared to the first thing in the morning. Not only that, your metabolism and lung functions are also working best in the late afternoon/evening, so you would have more strength and endurance to last through your cardio workout session.
Exercising in the evening gives you an outlet of stress release from the day’s work. You’ll also have a clearer mind to work out as it would be your final task for the day before hitting the sack.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
This is a story of not the most ignorant person I've ever met, but the first person who made me realize someone I knew and respected could be ignorant of something obvious.
 
It was my second year of college, and the US was gearing up to invade Iraq. Being at a liberal university, and hanging with an exceptionally liberal crowd even by my school's standards, everyone I knew was of course against the war, but no one more than one of my friends. I'll call her Rachael.
 
So, we all spent hours debating the war (stupid, really stupid, or worst decision ever?!), read article after article, printed out li
Continue Reading
This is a story of not the most ignorant person I've ever met, but the first person who made me realize someone I knew and respected could be ignorant of something obvious.
 
It was my second year of college, and the US was gearing up to invade Iraq. Being at a liberal university, and hanging with an exceptionally liberal crowd even by my school's standards, everyone I knew was of course against the war, but no one more than one of my friends. I'll call her Rachael.
 
So, we all spent hours debating the war (stupid, really stupid, or worst decision ever?!), read article after article, printed out little posters for our dormroom doors, went to protests, everything we could do, but Rachael was a step above. She didn't just protest, she went to every campus demonstration, big and small. She drove to other cities to protest no matter how much school work she had to do. She even organized groups and carpools to drive large groups of students to those protests with her. Every conversation we had at least reference the upcoming war for months. She talked about how this was our generation's moment to make a stand with a sincerity my cynical nature could never hope to imitate. She was the most dedicated activist of anyone I knew.
 
Then the invasion started, the US crushed the Iraqi army, and within a few weeks it was done (at least the initial invasion was). My generation couldn't stop it, but my friends were getting ready to protest such a senseless waste of life and money, and to keep protesting for as long as it took. We would soon be able to see that there were never any WMD's, never any connections to 9/11, that the whole thing was just a giant power grab. The day after Baghdad fell there was a knock on my door. It was Rachael.
 
“Jason, we won.”
 
“What do you mean?”
 
“The US won the war.”
 
“Well, of course we did. We were always going to win .”
 
“I thought we were protesting because we were going to lose.”
 
“…”
 
I will never, ever, argue that my side in a political debate holds the positions that we do because we are smarter or better educated than our opponents. Thanks for the lesson Rachael.

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article:
This is an entirely opinion based question, so don't expect any quality answers.
 
Running is cardio intensive, you're not going to get muscular, and you're more than likely going to run just about everyday. The gym is more for strength and size gains. You also don't exactly go to the gym everyday. You technically can, but you either have to work up to it for years or program it decreases in workload to keep your body from breaking down. 
 
Both take discipline and hard work.
 
Go with what matches your goal.

It was July 2003. Pisa, Italy.
 
I was standing no more than 80-100 meters away from the Leaning Tower of Pisa and enjoying the view when a blonde American man in his 30s, wearing sunglasses and a fishing hat approached me and tapped my shoulder.
 
-Excuse me - said the American man - do you know where I can find the Leaning Tower?
 
I turned my head in his direction, raised my eyebrows in disbelief and said:
 
-Please, follow me.
 
I walked a few meters to our right and he followed me. I pointed to the Leaning Tower and said:
 
-See that white building over there? That’s a tower. See how it’s making an angle with the ground? That means it’s leaning. And we’re in Pisa. It’s safe to say that’s the Leaning Tower of Pisa.
 
The man stared at the building and remained silent for a few seconds. He then turned his head at me and the following dialogue ensued:
 
-Are you sure? That’s a pretty ugly tower and I was told it was beautiful.
 
-Yes, I’m sure. It’s pretty obvious actually.
 
-Whoa. Well, that’s disappointing. Thank you! Good bye!
 
-Good bye.
 
He turned his back on me and went his way. To this day, almost 14 years later I haven’t forgotten the day I met that man, the most ignorant American I’ve ever met.

While I’m certain I’ve met dumber Americans than Veronica, it’s her story that comes to mind now. She was a young, incredibly voluptuous, if quite ditsy, receptionist at one of the first companies I’d worked for, and she had apparently screwed up something with a multimillion dollar contract pretty good because of something she said to a customer. Veronica was the daughter of a neighbor of the company owner, and assumed unfireable, but apparently my boss had had a few things to say about that particular screwup with Veronica’s boss.
 
I was their International Markets Analyst, and my boss, the Executive VP of Marketing & Sales, was a very cool guy who’d done a stint as a CIA Agent in Moscow, and after speaking with her boss he’d come into my office to discuss something else with me and the Inside Sales Manager. We’d just begun when Veronica burst into the room sobbing profusely, and managed to stammer out between wails, sniffles, and blowing her nose in a tissue that she was sorry for screwing everything up, but it had really hurt her feelings that he told her boss that she 
“was as dumb as a box of rocks!”
 More wails and sobs…
 
My boss just raised his eyebrows at her and said, “But that’s not true, Veronica, 
I never said that you were DUMB as a box of rocks. She was mistaken. I said that you were as SMART as a box of rocks!”
 
To the total amazement of both the Inside Sales Manager and I, she immediately brightened and cheerfully said, “Oh, then she got it completely 
backwards,
 I see now.
 
Okay.” With that, she turned and walked back out to go correct her boss. Our EVP shakes his head as he watches her walk out, then turns to us with a grin and says something about the impossibility of fixing stupid.
 
.

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
Rest!
 
The best part of doing one part a day is you get ample rest for that body part because you will train that body part again after a week.
 
That being said I have seen most of the professional bodybuilders training one body part per week. It helps them to train that body part intensely because they know it will always recover when they will train it again. There seems to me no other particular reason of training a body part per day!

3 most important parts of any skill development (my personal opinion)
Study
Observe
Practice
There is a dearth of information available online to understand workouts/exercise and their outcomes, so go ahead and read them. Try to filter out what is just bro-science and what is factual instructions/explanations. Go to some reputed or popular websites like 
Bodybuilding.com - Huge Online Supplement Store & Fitness Community!
 yes its not just for meat heads. 
YouTube
 is another very resourceful option.
 
The next step, observe everyone working out, when I say everyone i mean someone who impresses you with their skills from what you learnt above. Try to breakdown each move into steps and understand how the body is moving as a whole.
 
Its now time to stop leaning and start practicing, start with what seems to be manageable volume/intensity never stress yourself in your early stage. Start to feel every muscle that you think/read should be working. Once you have started to feel the actual muscle/muscle group being impacted by your movement you are good to start engaging them.
 
Each of these steps keep repeating, because there are so many ways to workout/train & exercise that you will never stop learning. The most import thing to remember is “listen to your body” it know what not to do. Anything that is making you very uncomfortable even in the slightest of ways, stop it and consult some one you know understands it.
 
Enjoy your workouts and achieve what you have in mind for your body.

Wait for it….
 
SAILING!!!

I had a friend in fourth grade. Let’s call him Fred. He wasn’t really the sharpest tool in the shed. He was also (as you might assume from the question) very ignorant about world events.
 
We were talking, and I brought up the topic of the September 11 attacks and Al-Qaeda. Fred asked me what Al-Qaeda was 
(facepalm) 
but I was used to it, coming from him at least. I explained what Al-Qaeda was and about the war in Afghanistan and all. I made remarks about how terrible it was that soldiers who were first graders on 9/11 were now fighting in Afghanistan.
 
My friend then said:
 
“Why don’t we just, like, nuke them all?”
 
Edit: According to him, he watched the news every day. Either that was a lie or he didn’t really pay attention. That was the reason I felt that he wouldn’t be as ignorant as most fourth graders on such topics.

I was quite confused and asked, “What language do you think we speak in Australia?” She looked confused, “Don’t you speak French?” Not that I’ve ever noticed.
 
It seemed to be a widespread belief though, because visiting a classmate who was doing a school exchange in another state, we attended her school f

When I was visiting the US, trying to buy clothing I asked the sales assistant to please help me with the sizing as the US size numbering system is different from what I was used to. “Where are you from?” she asked. “Australia,” I replied. “Oh my!” she said. “You speak remarkably good English.”
 
I was quite confused and asked, “What language do you think we speak in Australia?” She looked confused, “Don’t you speak French?” Not that I’ve ever noticed.
 
It seemed to be a widespread belief though, because visiting a classmate who was doing a school exchange in another state, we attended her school for the day. In her French class, one of her American classmates turned to me and said, “This should be really easy for you.”
 
Again I was confused, thinking, “How does he know I studied French at my high school?” I asked why he said that. “Don’t you speak French in Australia?” he replied. “Not unless we studied it in school or emigrated from France,” I told him.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
My daughters friend got in a tiff with her boyfriend, stomps outta the house gets in the car and takes off. Forgetting for the moment her tire is going flat.
 
Lucky for her she stops to get a soft drink at a gas station and sees how soft the tire is.
 
She gets flustered and loses the tire valve cap while trying to pump air. Frantically she looks for the cap before she pumps all the air … ahh, there it is !
 
She tells my daughter all this and adds "So I was able to keep all the air in the tire cuz I had the cap !"

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I worked for a German company that had World Wide manufacturing bases, including a factory in the US. Their CEO came to visit our British factory to find out how we were more efficient and more profitable than they were.
 
She was a big lass and a bonny lass. We called her Big Bird.
 
I was working a late shift and walked into the staff canteen to find her sat cross legged on one of the tables we eat off, facing away from me and letting rip a really juicy fart. I think that’s the most ignorant thing I ever saw and heard an American do.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
This happened at the US port of Entry in Mexico.
 
I had to get my visa stamped/re-validated in one of the neighboring US countries(Canada or Mexico only) in order to keep my I-94 up-to-date. Since Mexico is drive-able from where we live, we decided to get my visa stamped in Mexico. It took us 8 hours to drive up to Tijuana,and 4 hrs to shop around Mexico to make a “meaningful visit” and about 7 hrs to stand in a 3 mile long queue to re-enter the US. We finally get to the Visa officer whose name was ‘Gross’, I mean, his Last Name was ‘Gross’. I provide him with all the legal documents for the sta
Continue Reading
This happened at the US port of Entry in Mexico.
 
I had to get my visa stamped/re-validated in one of the neighboring US countries(Canada or Mexico only) in order to keep my I-94 up-to-date. Since Mexico is drive-able from where we live, we decided to get my visa stamped in Mexico. It took us 8 hours to drive up to Tijuana,and 4 hrs to shop around Mexico to make a “meaningful visit” and about 7 hrs to stand in a 3 mile long queue to re-enter the US. We finally get to the Visa officer whose name was ‘Gross’, I mean, his Last Name was ‘Gross’. I provide him with all the legal documents for the stamp. the conversation went like this:
 
Gross: (glancing at my passport) Are you from India?
 
Me: Yes, Sir.
 
Gross: I see your I-94 is out-of-date. Sorry, I cannot process this request.
 
Me: I have the documents from my Employer’s Attorney in order to revalidate my visa. Please read through them.
 
Gross: (goes through the docs) Madam- I would suggest you go to the US consulate in San Francisco and get your US visa ‘revalidated’. Sorry we don’t handle revalidation here. It looks like a very complicated case.
 
Me: What? US consulate in US?
 
Gross: (confused) Oh, isn't there one?
 
(After 2.5 hours of back-and-forth call with his supervisor and our Attorney).
 
Gross: Sorry, it might be true there is no US consulate in SFO. But we don’t do revalidation.
 
Me: (Appalled at his ignorance, not sure to cry or laugh) We need to talk to your supervisor.
 
(after 1.5 hours of waiting)
 
Supervisor: We are not familiar with this term revalidation.
 
(and directs us to his Supervisor after great reluctance)
 
Super Supervisor: (After hand-cuffing a drug racketer after a ‘go’ signal by a K-9, that happened to stand before us in the line !)
 
Sorry Madam, It is not a common term. All you need to have told the visa officer is nothing. It was just another term for ‘stamping’. Sorry again for the inconvenience.
 
(we for sure were amused and ‘Grossed’ out, at the same time!)
 
***———————————————————————————————————***
 
Woahh! Thank you Thank you! 300 Upvotes is the biggest I have ever gotten. Thanks all for your time and comments _/\_

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I hired a guy in a small Northern California town to do some work for me. I was not super happy with the quality of his work, but had a short timeline and few options, so decided to make the best of it. I made sure that I was paying him pretty well for his time and energy by market standards, so did not expect much guff.
 
At one point, just a few weeks before the project was due, he asked if I could please stop 
sending
 him project related emails late at night (my normal hours for such things). It was waking him up, he said, and besides he thought it was “unprofessional” for me to hit send while 
Continue Reading
I hired a guy in a small Northern California town to do some work for me. I was not super happy with the quality of his work, but had a short timeline and few options, so decided to make the best of it. I made sure that I was paying him pretty well for his time and energy by market standards, so did not expect much guff.
 
At one point, just a few weeks before the project was due, he asked if I could please stop 
sending
 him project related emails late at night (my normal hours for such things). It was waking him up, he said, and besides he thought it was “unprofessional” for me to hit send while he was sleeping. I should wait until his normal business hours to do so.
 
Note that at no point had I complained about him not responding to my messages late at night. In fact, I’d gone out of my way to establish with him that 48–72 hours was perfectly acceptable response time, otherwise I would call or text him if it was urgent. By definition, anything I emailed him was important and totally non-urgent
 
He literally thought that I should keep track of the hours that he and the other team members kept and only 
write 
emails during that time. He was quite adamant that it was, and I repeat this nincompoop’s words, “unprofessional” for me to do otherwise.
 
I was, in fact, dumbfounded and could not think of what to respond. In that moment, I could not think of anything in recent memory I’d personally heard with my own ears that was quite so ignorant.
 
The medium was designed, after all, so that person A could write and send it any old time that was convenient to them and person B could read and respond in turn when it suited them, in this way being just like paper mail, only faster. The recipient can set up whatever device (pc, tablet, phone) they receive email on anyway they like to suit their own preferences (which the sender could not possibly know). In other words, he could just silence notifications when he went to sleep (although for what I was paying him, he could easily have set up a temporary web-based mail account — for free — specifically for this project and only even logged in to it every few days).
 
Ironically, for 10–12 years of my career in high tech (in San Francisco/Silicon Valley) I specialized in email, in some cases rolling it out on a global scale for large companies. “Unprofessional”, therefore was not merely a ridiculous accusation in this context, but literally untrue.
 
Only later did it occur to me that I should have told him the only time I could sign his check would be late at night but, as a professional courtesy, would decline to do so.
 
If I’m wrong, by the way, someone please tell me in the comments. I’d hate to, like, write birthday and holiday cards or something when the people I’d send them to were taking a nap!
 
I know there are much more important issues to be ignorant on, but this one still stands out in my mind.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Ignorance, in my understanding, is to be defined with reference to a topic or area of knowledge.
 
For example a mechanical engineer may be ignorant of human anatomy. Thus it is not possible to identify “the most ignorant” person.
 
That said, let me recount couple of incidents. I was teaching Engineering Drawing to freshman
engineering students. I asked one student “what is one-half of two and a half?” He pulled out his calculator, fiddled with it some, then did something with pencil and paper and then gave his answer: “One-and-a-half”!
 
Again, another time, another student in Engineering Drawing cla

Ignorance, in my understanding, is to be defined with reference to a topic or area of knowledge.
 
For example a mechanical engineer may be ignorant of human anatomy. Thus it is not possible to identify “the most ignorant” person.
 
That said, let me recount couple of incidents. I was teaching Engineering Drawing to freshman
engineering students. I asked one student “what is one-half of two and a half?” He pulled out his calculator, fiddled with it some, then did something with pencil and paper and then gave his answer: “One-and-a-half”!
 
Again, another time, another student in Engineering Drawing class. As I go round and check their work, I saw this student had drawn a line at an angle to a horizontal line, whereas he was supposed to draw a perpendicular. I pointed it out and told him “the line is not perpendicular.” He replied: “It looks straight to me!”
 
For me, these are examples of extreme ignorance of basic math and geometry considering these are engineering majors!

i have to agree with Dan Hunter, bread really makes the sandwich. growing up in the ’70s and ’80s in the south (U.S.) eating commercial white bread, i didn’t really understand that, but now i do.
 
i remember the first couple of times traveling to spain and seeing sandwiches everywhere, a thin baguette with just a tiny bit of ham and cheese and thinking what nerve they had calling that a sandwich and charging that kind of price.
 
because i was thinking in the subway/blimpie frame of mind — what you put on the bread is what you’re paying for and the spanish sandwiches looked pretty skimpy on the fillings.
 
it didn’t take me long to realize the bread was a key element of the sandwich, versus being simply a carrier for the filling. it was eye-opening.
 
good bread is really the most essential part of a sandwich, and it depends on the sandwich, as well! for example, sometimes even the lowly loaf of white bread is just the right thing for a certain type of sandwich. just as a hearty slice of rye is perfect for others.
 
my second favorite sandwich ingredient is probably … … … this is tough … … … i’m going to go with ham.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
Sure, you can even put on muscle.
 
For years I overtrained, 2 sessions a day a one time. I then cut back on gym time and transferred my obsession to cycling. The best I ever got was after working in Slovakia for a few months, where I only trained at weekends. I returned to Thailand and subsequently won my 1st race back.
 
Well that turned out to be my only 1st place - although I still got the occasional podium after resuming overtraining.
 
I stopped racing and started back in the gym about 5 years ago. Every other day, I gradually improved but never got near to where I was before.
 
Almost 3 years ago I had a change of circumstances and now train at most 5 times a fortnight- and often only have time twice a week.
 
I can't squat shit anymore, or bench press nearly as much either but on curls I'm only about 10kg off my best- and my best was 25 years ago!
 
Dorian Yates famously said : “ If training 10 hours a day and eating dog shit was the way to be a winner, I'd have done it. As it is you need first to shock your muscles and then let them rebuild, this takes longer than 24 hours”. He won 6 back to back Mr Olympia titles.
 
So my 2 cents is : pretty fast, to get your heart rate up and moderately heavy is the way to go. I'm now 64 and maintaining as much muscle mass is no longer just for asthenics, it's Essential for a a mobile and healthy old age.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: Something that I think is especially “ignorant” is a misuse of the word ignorant. Ignorant is a neutral word meaning “not knowing,” and everyone on the face of the earth is ignorant of something. To use “ignorant” as a negative word to mean “stupid” to me is, quite frankly, “ignorant.” So my answer to this question is people who can't properly use “ignorant.” Those are the most ignorant people I have met in America.
