Mayonnaise
: Some people may not like it. However I do love it not only because it tastes good, but it can also help moisten the sandwich. From my experience, if you don’t spread mayo on your sandwich, it can be very dry for you to swallow your sandwich.
Caramelised Onion
: It adds an amazing sweetness to your sandwich. Sweat your onions (I prefer red onions personally) with some oil, and then add your balsamic vinegar & sugar, let the it reduce until you end up with a soft caramelised onions.
Bacon
: Just because it’s good haha.
Gherkin
: Adds a slight sourness, and when eaten together with other ingredients in the sandwich, it complements the whole thing very well.
Smoke
: When I’m in the mood for it, I like to grill my sandwich. The smokiness from the grill just adds another layer of flavour. I said this because I believe the term “Flavour” is the quality of something that can trigger your 5 senses (taste, smell, hear, sight, feel/touch).

title: How to workout
article:
You can make your workout time more effective by squeezing in AS MUCH WORK AS YOU CAN into the time you have.
 
Most people mistakenly assume that the amount of time they spend at the gym/working is directly proportional to their results.
 
Nothing can be further from the truth.
 
You can spend 2 hours in the gym, but if you take long breaks between sets, spend time swiping up and down your social media accounts, or just yapping with your buddies, you’re probably not working hard enough.

You can make your workout time more effective by squeezing in AS MUCH WORK AS YOU CAN into the time you have.
 
Most people mistakenly assume that the amount of time they spend at the gym/working is directly proportional to their results.
 
Nothing can be further from the truth.
 
You can spend 2 hours in the gym, but if you take long breaks between sets, spend time swiping up and down your social media accounts, or just yapping with your buddies, you’re probably not working hard enough.
Similarly, if you only have 30 minutes in the gym, but you cram 20 sets of intense lifting into that time, you’ll leave a pool of sweat on the gym floor and create an awesome stimulus for results.
 
I’ve seen this question asked many times, so I’ve written an article to explain.
 
How Much Time Should You Spend In The Gym? (HINT: Wrong Question!)
Good luck.

article:

I’ve spent hours in horror reading these replies. It’s like rubbernecking at a car crash; you want to look away but can’t.
 
Making this anonymous so as not to embarrass the in-law who was about to have her first baby. She asked my wife what labor was like. She was obviously a little anxious about things, so my wife tried to assure her she’d get through it. Then they got to the part about the actual delivery, when the in-law asks:
 
“So how does that work? Do you have to be totally naked, or can you, like, wear a swimsuit or something?”
 
My wife also reminded me recently of the interview she sat in on with her old boss. They were looking for someone to work the reception desk, and the applicant was an Englishwoman who’d moved to the USA. Apparently the interview was going well until my wife’s boss said, “You seem really nice, and you’re qualified enough, but we’d really prefer a native English speaker to answer our phones. Now, I realize English isn’t your first language, so would you be comfortable handling the phones?” My wife said the applicant flashed her a WTF look, while my wife facepalmed as subtly as she could.
 
Then there was another in-law who didn’t realize the sun is the closest star to Earth.
 
And a former co-worker of my wife who loved sweating when she worked out. Why? Because sweat is melted fat. So if you’re sweating, you’re losing weight.
 
Or another of her co-workers (she has all the fun stories) who insisted on correcting my wife when she brought a quesadilla back to the office for lunch.
 
Co-worker: “That smells good. What is that?”
 
Wife: “Just a quesadilla I got down the street.”
 
Co-worker: “A what?”
 
Wife: “A quesadilla.”
 
Co-worker: “Ohhh. You mean a KWAY-sa-DIL-la.”
 
Wife: “No, I’m pretty sure I mean a quesadilla.”
 
Co-worker: “No, you’re pronouncing it wrong. I took Spanish.”
 
Wife, who actually did take four years of Spanish in high school: “Oh, my bad.”

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article: I am from Canada and while on a training course around 1979 in Chicago, I was working with a coloured guy from New Orleans. I was a little taken a back when he quite seriously asked me if all us Canadians live in igloos up there? I said sure, and in summer when they melt, we build log cabins to live in and when winter comes around again we burn the cabins to keep the igloos warm! Not sure if he believed me?

article:

He shut up and turned bright red. Of course he didn’t have any money…. in the past I’d helped him move and other stuf

There was a guy I called Crazy Joe, once I gave him a ride cuz he was always broke and didn’t have a car, and like always he just wanted to argue without listening, and I was explaining to him that I believe in socialism/communism because we should all help each other, and he kept insisting that capitalism was best because nobody had any motivation to do anything without profit… I was getting annoyed, and finally pulled the car over and told him he owed me $45 for taxi service. He shut up and turned bright red. Of course he didn’t have any money…. in the past I’d helped him move and other stuff for free. I guess that was the last time I ever talked to him.
 
The other one that always bothered me was this nice Israeli lady who ran this nice little gyro shop that I’d eat at. One day for whatever reason we started talking about all the issues over there, and I was arguing that Palestinians have at least some reason to be upset about how they’ve been treated. Think what you want about Israel, but you can’t deny that Palestinians have had a rough time… and she just exploded, “They are animals. Every fucking one of them… they should be shot like dogs.” I was like, oh ok, so this is what racism looks like, and I never went back.

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article: Total body workouts also improve proprioception the ability to tell where your body is in space. Better proprioceptive abilities improve balance and help prevent falls. With full-body training, you aren’t just strengthening and hypertrophying muscles, you’re training them in an integrated manner. Such an approach pays off with additional dividends you don’t get from focusing on one muscle group at a time.

article:

Rack session to failure: Squats, Bench press, Deadlifts, Rack pulls, and Shoulder press. I do this on the smith so I can remain at the same rack. This is great for my lazy days, and when the gym is packed.
 
Biking: Stationary bike or bmx. BMX, you pretty much have to stand and actually put in the work to get over different terrain, unlike the typical bike which has gears to adjust. The stationary bike, I like, I can get my 10–24 miles in without the wear tear of terrain.

Personally I enjoy fully body rack sessions, biking, and running.
 
Rack session to failure: Squats, Bench press, Deadlifts, Rack pulls, and Shoulder press. I do this on the smith so I can remain at the same rack. This is great for my lazy days, and when the gym is packed.
 
Biking: Stationary bike or bmx. BMX, you pretty much have to stand and actually put in the work to get over different terrain, unlike the typical bike which has gears to adjust. The stationary bike, I like, I can get my 10–24 miles in without the wear tear of terrain.
 
Running: I like for hiit. I tend to run in intervals. 5 minutes straight running, 3 minutes walking, 3minutes running, 5 mins walking, 10 running, 1 walking, 4min run, etc. On the treadmill it’s different, there’s not a lot of impact on my feet and legs from terrain. This way I can protect my feet, and legs from micro trauma and lowers the risk of re-injury. I do this for about 30–60mins.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
You ever see a snowball start at the top of a hill the size of an orange, roll down, and knock over something bigger than a house?
 
I have.
Mama Mia!
 
In all seriousness, research shows there is no better time of day physiologically to workout. Some studies point to more strength in the evening. While others say working out in the morning on an empty stomach boosts fat burning. Either way, there is no scientific consensus about which time of day is better to workout.
 
However, working out in the morning has extreme psychological, financial, and time advantages. 
You may start the size of an orange, bu
Continue Reading
You ever see a snowball start at the top of a hill the size of an orange, roll down, and knock over something bigger than a house?
 
I have.
Mama Mia!
 
In all seriousness, research shows there is no better time of day physiologically to workout. Some studies point to more strength in the evening. While others say working out in the morning on an empty stomach boosts fat burning. Either way, there is no scientific consensus about which time of day is better to workout.
 
However, working out in the morning has extreme psychological, financial, and time advantages. 
You may start the size of an orange, but with these advantages, working out in the morning will have you knocking over Bowser-sized barriers.
You will start your work day knowing you have accomplished more than everyone else at the office. The increased confidence will carry over into your work and promotions will come more easily earning you sizably more income over time.
You will begin showering at the gym saving money on your water bill. You will buy less toilet paper because you’re more…
regular
 at work. Also, by leaving the house earlier you can set your thermostat to kick into energy savings mode earlier, which also saves you money.
You see just how sluggish your coworkers are in the first few hours of every day. You are able to run laps around them in terms of production in the first few hours. In morning meetings you are sharper than everyone else and can impress your boss when he too is likely not thinking as clearly yet.
You have no distractions keeping you from working out in the morning like you normally do in the evening. No emails to answer. No kids to deal with. No projects to finish. No spur of the moment coworker happy hours to keep you from working out.
Your work clothes will fit a little tighter or a little looser in all the right places giving you even more confidence.
You won’t feel as guilty about eating that piece of birthday cake someone brought to the office because you’ve already burned your calories in the morning.
You will have more truly free time after work do do whatever you want. No more feeling guilty for skipping a workout to join friends for dinner.
You will no longer have that nagging, itching pain of tired eyes in the morning. (If you don’t think you have this pain, you are probably so accustomed to it you don’t even know it exists. Try working out in the morning for a week.)
You are more likely to eat healthier throughout the day because you don’t want to waste a workout you’ve already done.
You will actually have more energy and motivation throughout the day due to an increased loci of control.
You will find yourself able to ditch your morning coffee because of the endorphins released from working out. This will save you a ton of money over time.
You will be surrounded by other like minded, success oriented people at the gym in the morning. You will meet some of these people and make more valuable connections. One of these connections might lead to a better job or business opportunity.
Workout in the evening or in the morning. Physically you will not see much of a difference.
 
But if you want to become a giant snowball and knock over Bowser…
 
Workout in the morning!

title: How to workout
article:
Something you can tolerate doing every day.
 
Consistency is important for good health habits to work, so consider what routine you could realistically and reliably commit to (say) every day for the next month or so. Don’t be heroic. You’re just trying to establish a habit. You can add to it later, but initially, select something that you can get through in 10 minutes or less.
 
(If you habitually start the day with a cup of coffee or tea, you can build on that existing habit by exercising while you’re waiting for the water to boil. That’s 5 minutes. You can do this.)

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article: If you meant poor by knowledge then I am poor by knowledge. I joined Quora to earn some knowledge from the awesomely talented people present here. If poor means financially poor then I can say that I am poor as well as middle class. Since I am a student all my expenses are paid by my father. I don't possess money earned by me so I am poor. In the other hand I don't have to face any financial problems because my father takes care of it all. In this way since I enjoy all the facilities a poor person doesn't have access to I am not poor.

title: Are there any poor people on Quora, as Internet access is very cheap nowadays?
article: This question made me laugh. First off lets address the internet access is cheap. I live in a rural area, you know what I have to pay? $130 a month for 100 gb. This leads into the other part. Because I have to pay so much for internet I cannot afford to have TV. Hope that answers your question. If it does not though we have a $50,000 income a year, but because of mortgage and the ever growing expense of groceries and rising prices of utilities we cannot even afford TV. And our mortgage is cheaper then most places cost for rent.

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
I think full body workouts kick the shit out of split routines.
 
There’s no comparison.
 
That being said…let’s compare them!
 
Full body routine advantages
High frequency of 
muscle protein synthesis
. Compared with the split routine, every muscle group is getting hit multiple times per week, meaning that it leads to more muscle growth (see chart below, FFM 1.1% increase in the full body group vs .4% increase in the split group)
More fat loss
. Studies consistently show that full body routines cause better fat loss, often double or more of that of a split routine. (see chart below, -5.7% fat loss for full
Continue Reading
I think full body workouts kick the shit out of split routines.
 
There’s no comparison.
 
That being said…let’s compare them!
 
Full body routine advantages
High frequency of 
muscle protein synthesis
. Compared with the split routine, every muscle group is getting hit multiple times per week, meaning that it leads to more muscle growth (see chart below, FFM 1.1% increase in the full body group vs .4% increase in the split group)
More fat loss
. Studies consistently show that full body routines cause better fat loss, often double or more of that of a split routine. (see chart below, -5.7% fat loss for full body, vs -2.1% for split group)
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4885621/
Triple the fat loss and triple the muscle growth? Sign me up!
More frequent 
practice 
with the movements-that could explain why the bench results were very similar above (simple movement) but the full body group got better squat gains (more complex movement). They just had more 
practice
.
Sorry…I just love that video.
 
Full body routine disadvantages
They’re 
hard
. This is BY FAR the main reason people gravitate towards bro splits. Mentally, going into the gym and working your entire body just is on another plane of existence in terms of difficulty compared to just working one chunk of muscle, even if the volume is the same. It’s easy to tap out when you have to do front squats, RDLs, bench press, overhead press, seated rows, pulldowns, lateral raises, curls, extensions and ab wheel all in the same day.
Perhaps because of this, they can be tough on your 
hormone levels
. Check the above chart; the full body testosterone went up 11%, but the split went up 21%! Keep in mind this was just four weeks, working out just three times per week, as well. Keeping up a full body protocol all the time, for higher volumes could 
probably 
lead to reductions in T for some people.
They give you 
less time 
to 
recover
. This is part of the reason that I really am sure to use a lot of variety in my training when incorporating higher frequency. If you use the same movements all the time, be prepared for your joints to be unhappy. You need to vary the movement patterns enough that it shifts the stress on the joints at least slightly.
Split routine advantages
More 
recovery time 
for each body part between workouts.
Might have better satellite cell activation (check the answer below) due to the 
increased concentrated workload 
and greater 
muscle damage
. 
Geoffrey Verity Schofield's answer to How fast does lost muscle grow back with muscle memory?
Get a 
better pump
-doing more work in one session can lead to greater metabolic stress for that muscle.
Can help you develop a better 
mind-muscle connection. 
Yes, that’s a real thing, especially for the upper body.
Causes increased 
soreness
, which can facilitate growth and let you “feel” that muscle better. This could be a disadvantage if you don’t like this feeling…I personally kinda like it for some twisted reason.
Split routine disadvantages
Lower frequency 
per muscle group. This is probably the biggest reason why split routines suck. You do chest on Monday (obviously), and your chest is really only growing for about 36–48hours afterwards. There are 168 hours of the week-why would you only have each muscle group growing 20–30% of the time? 
Not optimal! 
Full body routines can get that number up to 70–80+% for the entire body, which explains the massive difference in both muscle gain and fat loss.
You 
can 
actually 
LOSE muscle
. In the above example, you’re growing on Monday, Tuesday and maybe Wednesday. You might be maintaining on Thursday and Friday. But especially if you are cutting or not getting in enough protein, or not sleeping well, it’s entirely possible for the weekend to be in a catabolic state.
Not that kind of Weaknd; he’s in a catabolic state 24/7
You can 
lose “touch” 
with an exercise. This isn’t gonna happen with bicep curls or lateral raises, but with something like squatting or Olympic lifting, it’s entirely possible for the nervous system to slightly forget how to do these movements if you’re only doing them once per week.
All in all, I’d do full body 
most 
of the time, but if you hit a plateau, splitting up your routine can be a nice change of pace.
 
You’ll have more time to recover, and can really focus on blasting a body part to force it to grow, perhaps through the aforementioned satellite cells. You can recover any hormonal or structural stress incurred during your full body bonanza.
 
I’ve taken a page out of Eric Helm’s book
and been doing full body workouts 4–6 times a week recently, and it’s been astonishingly effective. Tough…but the gains have been impressive.
 
But, I won’t do it for the rest of my life, as it’s not sustainable.
 
Check out my new 
Space
, 
follow me on 
Instagram
 
for daily diet and training tips! Subscribe to my 
YouTube
 
channel for longer form, informative content.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I'm Irish and was on a trip to Florida. I was in a café and was talking to someone working there. When she found out I was Irish she then asked:
 
A) “ Have you ever seen a leprechaun?” It amazed me to think that she actually thought we had magical creatures running around.
 
B) “Are there cars in Ireland?” I was very tempted to say “No and I swam across the Pacific Ocean to get here.” It shocked me that she didn't know that Ireland was a first world/developed country when she claimed she was Irish herself (Her great great great great great great grandfather was Irish).

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
In 2012 I went on an illustration summer course in the Dominican Republic and I had the chance to study with three US people. After a few days we became good friends and had lots of conversation. Once we were talking about America (REAL NAME FOR THIS CONTINENT, NOT THE UNITED STATES) and one of them was pretty sure the Dominican Republic was part of the land of the US, not a Central American island with Haiti on the other side.
 
At the moment seemed like a big discovery for this person then we made fun of it.
 
That was a case of ignorance, but they were great people. Hope to see them soon again.

article:

To gain muscle, you need a couple of things:
regular stimulus to adapt
fuel to make adaptation
So I wont go on about the second point- to keep that simple, aim for 14x your body weight(lb) or 31x body weight(kg) in calories, and add as necessary.
 
But for working out- 2 factors come into play
 
Consistency

When can you workout consistently?

Short answer: 
It depends…
 
To gain muscle, you need a couple of things:
regular stimulus to adapt
fuel to make adaptation
So I wont go on about the second point- to keep that simple, aim for 14x your body weight(lb) or 31x body weight(kg) in calories, and add as necessary.
 
But for working out- 2 factors come into play
 
Consistency
 and 
Energy.
 
To choose a time (because neither in inherently “better”)- 
 
When do you have the most energy?
When can you workout consistently?
 
If you aren’t a morning person; or can’t workout without eating- the early morning isn’t going to work for you.
 
Conversely, if there’s no way in heck you have the time or energy to workout after work, that time probably won’t work.
In the afternoon, you are more likely to have fuel in your system
In the morning you are possibly able to carve out/ schedule a regular time.
Summary:
An ‘okay’ plan, 90% of the time, works better than the ‘perfect’ plan 50% of the time. 
With everything- It depends, what works for you?

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
It's a toss up between the numerous Americans who don't realise Australian is an English-speaking country and a girl I met on a tour many years ago who didn't realise America was significantly older than Australia in terms of colonisation.
 
It was 1993, and we were in Europe and I was marvelling at the architecture and the idea that people had been walking cobbled streets for a millennium or more. I said to her in terms of buildings and architecture that Aus was a baby in comparison, being just over 200 years old (First Fleet was 1788) so we didn't have that same sense of history in terms of anc
Continue Reading
It's a toss up between the numerous Americans who don't realise Australian is an English-speaking country and a girl I met on a tour many years ago who didn't realise America was significantly older than Australia in terms of colonisation.
 
It was 1993, and we were in Europe and I was marvelling at the architecture and the idea that people had been walking cobbled streets for a millennium or more. I said to her in terms of buildings and architecture that Aus was a baby in comparison, being just over 200 years old (First Fleet was 1788) so we didn't have that same sense of history in terms of ancient roads, buildings and artifacts. She replied the US was the same, only dating to 1776.
 
We were 22 and I had never studied American history, so I tentatively mentioned Columbus and the Spanish, and then said, “And weren't you a British colony before that (meaning 1776)?”Her response? “Oh, were we?” I asked her if she celebrated Independence Day. And she did. I have no idea what she thought she was celebrating on July 4th…
 
I found it odd that she didn't know such a basic piece of her country's history.

A lot of foreigners (non US) will tell their stories about ignorance of the American public about geography.
 
And indeed, during my first trip to the US, I met educated locals - software engineers - who didn't know in which country London is in Europe; I thought they were kidding, but nope. Even more common were Americans who would think that Switzerland lies North of France or that it holds most of the Alps (Switzerland comes in 4th place, well behind the top 3 
Alpine states
, Austria, Italy, France, whether in area or in population)! And to rebound on another post, you'd surprise most of them if you'd reveal that Azerbaijan is a member state of the Council of Europe.
 
I have traveled extensively during my first 55+ years of existence (still holding 3 simultaneously valid passports just to cope with visa stamping) and I have not seen this level of ignorance matched anywhere else. I guess geography is not the forte of the US education system.
 
But when it comes to rescuing a threatened allied nation, Americans don't ask where it is located. 
They
 
simply
 
come
…
 
So, what? Do we complain then about their education system?
And for those who haven't had the luck to see what the Alps are like, have a 
look
 near my place.
 
Best wishes to the world for a happy 2017
 :)

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
Hi Brad,
 
I can't say for definite which way is better. I have tried both and I found both to be effective.
 
Even today, most of my workout is focused on the morning where I put in an average of 45 min to an hour. Some days, I get a window to go for walks or do short sprints in the evening and I go for it.
 
What really matters here is consistency. Do you have the time and discipline to do 2 sessions of 30 min in a day? Then go for it. But if you are pressed for time, then select the time of day which works best for you and schedule your exercise accordingly.
 
Cheers
 
Rajiv

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:

I told him no, and he said (and I quote): “Stop lying, you fucking Nazi. There’s no such thing as German, all who claim that are Nazi.”
 
It took me literally 30 minutes to explain to this guy that the Nazis were a political party, not a race. I think he still didn’t believe me at the end.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
Does someone my mum met count?
 
Anyway, my mum and her sister wanted to eat out- they were in Chicago at that time, around 1994, I think? At the restaurant, some dude was sitting on the table next to them.
 
So, my mum was chatting casually with her sister in our traditional language when the man walked up to them. “Excuse me. Are you from Africa?” He said, quite politely.
 
They both nodded, so he continued. “Is it true you live in trees?”
 
My mum had stared at him for a moment before replying with a kind smile, “We also cook on stones.”
 
Unfortunately, he didn't realize she was being sarcastic.

“No guns allowed
”
 
True story.
 
As a kid, during one of my numerous vacation family trips to the USA (I think it was to L.A.), we were having the usual fun visiting Disneyland and Toys R Us, and then it was time to go back.
 
This was post 9/11, which I remember because of what happened next.
 
Inside the airport, during one of the security checks we were suddenly stopped by a TSA employee.
 
TSA employee: “
Sir, you can’t take these on board
”.
 
Dad: “
What do you mean? Why?”.
 
TSA: “
Guns are not allowed”.
 
Dad: “
Guns? These aren’t guns; these are toys”.
 
She was talking about these:
These are 1:6 scale toys, not gun replicas.
I swear to God this happened. I’m not religious, but I still swear to god. And I would if I were.
 
Back in the day, my dad, my brothers, and I were in love with those toys, GI Joe, and another brand named “Elite Force”, and we used to collect everything we found. Guns, uniforms, soldiers, pilots, etc.
 
TSA: “
Sorry, sir, it clearly says that we can’t allow you to board the plane with guns
”.
 
So, after a heated argument between my dad and her, regarding the difference and similitudes between guns and toys shaped like guns, she told my dad that he needed to take them out of the packaging, talk with the airline, and, if still allowed, take them as checked baggage.
 
Long story short, since we were in a hurry, my father reluctantly put those toys in a common plastic bag, ran over to the check-in counters and back, and boarded the plane in justified anger.
 
We thought those toys were gonna disappear (
if suitcases with padlocks are often illegally opened, what’s a plastic bag full of toys
?)
, 
so we gave up on them early. They did arrive a couple of days later, though.
 
Maybe it was ignorance, maybe it was stupidity, maybe it was both; maybe they were real orders. But what an ignorant, stupid person 
and 
order. The disappointment and frustration of that experience are still there.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was on vacation in Florida with my family some years ago, at a restaurant. We’re from Canada, specifically Halifax, Nova Scotia on the east coast (right next to Maine). It’s the largest city east of Quebec/Montreal, a major port, and a naval base (it’s also a frequent port of call for cruise ships and military vessels). So it’s quite well known, even if you don’t know much about it you’ve probably heard of the place at the very least. My dad was even wearing a red Canada flag ball cap.
 
Making conversation, our waitress asked us where I’m from. I said we’re on vacation, from Halifax. She gave 
Continue Reading
I was on vacation in Florida with my family some years ago, at a restaurant. We’re from Canada, specifically Halifax, Nova Scotia on the east coast (right next to Maine). It’s the largest city east of Quebec/Montreal, a major port, and a naval base (it’s also a frequent port of call for cruise ships and military vessels). So it’s quite well known, even if you don’t know much about it you’ve probably heard of the place at the very least. My dad was even wearing a red Canada flag ball cap.
 
Making conversation, our waitress asked us where I’m from. I said we’re on vacation, from Halifax. She gave me an odd quizzical look. Halifax Nova Scotia, I went on. It’s on the east coast.
 
“I’ve never heard of that country before. It’s on the east? Like by New York?”
 
“No, I’m from Canada,” trying to keep it together.
 
“Oh, but you said you were from Nover Scotia.” Confused look intensifies.
 
“Haha yeah, I did. I’m from Halifax. In Nova Scotia, Canada. It’s right next to Maine.”
 
She pauses for a couple moments and seems to be rallying all available brain power to handle this onslaught of information. When she finally replies it’s in an almost questioning, cheerful voice:
 
“Oh!.. You’re from the lobster place! You should have just said so instead of all that other confusing stuff”

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I don’t know if a meta-answer is permissible, but every time I encounter an answer to this question it strikes me that bring surprised by ignorance is itself a bit ignorant Ignorance, after all, is the default state. No matter how obvious a fact may seem to be, you aren’t born knowing it. History and geography are simply not emphasized in American schools; but more than that, the message isn’t conveyed that grown up human beings should know about such things. Under the circumstances, it’s hardly a wonder if an American kid can’t find France on a map. If anything is worthy of surprise or, more 
Continue Reading
I don’t know if a meta-answer is permissible, but every time I encounter an answer to this question it strikes me that bring surprised by ignorance is itself a bit ignorant Ignorance, after all, is the default state. No matter how obvious a fact may seem to be, you aren’t born knowing it. History and geography are simply not emphasized in American schools; but more than that, the message isn’t conveyed that grown up human beings should know about such things. Under the circumstances, it’s hardly a wonder if an American kid can’t find France on a map. If anything is worthy of surprise or, more to the point, of concern, it ought to be that our institutions do such a rotten job of informing people or making them want to inform themselves. Of course it isn’t just the schools that fail. I reserve a large portion of my scorn for the Society for the Promotion of Public Ignorance that is American journalism.

title: Is it bad to do full body workouts every day?
article:
It depends on what your purpose is. If your want to strengthen your nervous system then you can workout the whole body everyday. You just have to make sure you do not more than 5 reps on a moderately difficult exercise and don’t exert your muscles too much and keep them fresh. By the way this won’t help you add more muscles though you could still get strong like Bruce Lee.
 
And if you want to get more ripped or add muscles you have to go all in and breakdown your muscles. But you can’t do work out on whole body everyday as your muscles would need lots of rest. If you do workout everyday you are 
Continue Reading
It depends on what your purpose is. If your want to strengthen your nervous system then you can workout the whole body everyday. You just have to make sure you do not more than 5 reps on a moderately difficult exercise and don’t exert your muscles too much and keep them fresh. By the way this won’t help you add more muscles though you could still get strong like Bruce Lee.
 
And if you want to get more ripped or add muscles you have to go all in and breakdown your muscles. But you can’t do work out on whole body everyday as your muscles would need lots of rest. If you do workout everyday you are likely to fatigue and put excess pressure on the muscles and cause injury. This is also one of the reason why workout geeks have a separate leg day, back day, chest day so by the time the particular muscle part has to be worked upon next time it has got enough rest.

There are TONS of workouts online for kettle bell training that uses full body movements like kettle bell swings, squats, thrusters, anything and everything. Not only is this an awesome workout but it will burn more calories for you too. 
 
In terms of diet, if your only issue is cravings then you're in good shape. If you are craving salt a lot then you are quite possibly dehydrated. Try to drink at least 3 litres of water daily. When you are craving a snack, try and g
Continue Reading
The best thing for you to do in terms of exercise is to get a couple of kettle bells, they look like a cannon ball with a handle. There are TONS of workouts online for kettle bell training that uses full body movements like kettle bell swings, squats, thrusters, anything and everything. Not only is this an awesome workout but it will burn more calories for you too. 
 
In terms of diet, if your only issue is cravings then you're in good shape. If you are craving salt a lot then you are quite possibly dehydrated. Try to drink at least 3 litres of water daily. When you are craving a snack, try and go for something that is more protein than a carb. My favourite healthy snack is carrots and hummus, they help me out a ton. Protein shakes help a ton as well because they keep you satiated and feeling full between meals.
 
Let me know if you have any other questions but you'll do great, 30 mins per day is more than enough time to sculpt that physique!
 
-Mike

As of this moment in time, I prefer running first and yoga second. I hated running in middle and high school (anything before, I probably enjoyed, but don't remember much), mostly because it was forced upon me by the school administration in the form of pacers and the infamous 1 mile runs. 
 
Once college hit and I began to realize that my health is actually on my shoulders, I ventured into the world of yoga, mainly because it doesn't involve any kind of traditional cardio (i.e. running). I never tried bikram, but hard-core classes like power yoga or advanced vinyasa flow made you sweat and toned and super freakishly flexible. I began jogging when I realized that my heart rate wasn't going as fast as when I first started, and weirdly enough it didn't feel like a work-out without breathing hard. 
 
The first time I ran more than 2 miles was mind-boggling. And then I ran a 5k (on my own, not in a race and rather slowly), I literally thought I was dreaming and pinched myself. Compared to other avid runners, I'm quite slow, I average probably 10min/mile to 12min/mile depending on the day, but each time I hit another distance (like 5 miles, etc) or time goals (like 5k in 30min, etc), it hooked me. Of course I have days where I absolutely loath putting my running shoes, so I substitute yoga. 
 
One thing that I have noticed with running more often for longer times and distances is that you can get extremely tight quadriceps, hamstrings, glutes, gastrocnemius, essentially all your leg muscles and your abs. So I'm not as stretchy and yoga is actually a bit more painful (I appreciate wooden people's yoga feats more now), which in turn led me to more running. So lots of stretching and sprinkling of yoga along with some healthy goals and good running shoes resulted in this weird love for running. :)

article:

As Cameron says, I go to a gym frequently but I don’t recall ever hitting it.
 
I had my knee replaced in September of last year, and the rehab exercises I was shown can best be performed on various resistance machines of the sort you can only really get at a well-equipped gym.
 
When I started back to work, I took advantage of our university’s brand new recreation center with state-of-the-art equipment to continue my rehab efforts, and decided to work the rest of my old bod as well.
 
So I do aerobic stints on the stationary bike (very knee-friendly) controlled leg work on the leg press, leg curl, hip addiction/abduction machine, and the regular suite of upper-body work as well.
 
This has been working very well and at my age (70) I’m making good progress with overall strength and my knee is coming along nicely.
 
(Takes up to a full year for complete healing)
 
Here’s a minor peeve of mine. The use of the term “gym” as a synonym for “lifting weights”. Our gym has the full suite of both resistance equipment and aerobic equipment. Bikes, steppers, elliptical, rowing, treadmill, etc.
 
In addition, there’s indoor basketball courts, swimming, spinning, yoga, Pilates, etc, etc. You can do pretty much any sort of activity you like, and this is the case with many commercial gyms.

I worked at a historic house museum built in 1815. The way I wrote my tour was to give the history of the house and its residents in the context of US history while physicaly moving around the space.
 
In the front yard, I'd talk about the Revolutionary War and the founding of the county, at the front door I’d talk about the war of 1812 and family that built the house, inside I talked more about the people and everyday life, etc…
 
In the kitchen we talk about servants and slaves. The to the slave quarters to talk about slavery in the state. Then to the servants’ quarters to compare. Then to the family’s bedrooms to compare that. There are photos and furniture from the mid/late 1800s so I talk about what the family did during the civil war and how/why/when they freed their slaves and the freedmen’s community that grew alongside the property.
 
One tourist looked at me at this part of the tour in surprise and asked, “"so this was in slavery times?”
 
She not only didn't know when slavery was in the context of US history, because she was paying attention during the Rev War and 1812 section of the tour, but she some how zoned out during all of my beautiful social history prose with documents and props and everything!
 
I learned to be a better judge of guests’ attention spans.

Three times a week would be enough and rest can be made up for by introducing a good diet plan.

title: What are the pros and cons of training full-body every day?
article:
Cons? I don’t see any. That’s what I do….Twice a week I do a 14-exercise program that covers all the major muscle groups. Works very well for me as an old guy trying to maintain fitness, muscle mass, and bone health.
 
Probably would not be optimal for a juicy young bodybuilder…. They tend to do complicated “split” programs and work out more often.
 
Strength trainers and athletes tend to do fewer exercises and again, usually twice a week.
 
You have to take your goals into consideration.

Establish a workout routine with these 6 elements as most experts agree a well-balanced exercise program should have these 6 elements:
 
1. Aerobics - Cardio Fitness and Training
.
 
2. Strength and Resistance and Core Exercise Programs
 
3. Additional Strength and Resistance Program and Core Program for Variety as this variety will keep you motivated.
 
4. Stability and Balance Training.
 
5. Flexibility Maintenance - Stretching.
 
6. Variety in Workouts.
 
Exercise programs become boring. It’s important to know how to keep your exercise program interesting and something you look forward to doing. We wrote a book “Golf Fitness: An All Inclusive Workout Program for Golfers Only” which has all six elements plus different exercises which are important to change your routine and keep you motivated and help you make workouts become more interesting.
 
Most of us have a daily routine of getting up in the morning, going to work, coming home, etc. Visualize yourself going to the gym as a vacation or a holiday from your daily routine.
 
You should change your exercises if you’ve been going to the gym on schedule and you don’t see any improvement. If you train the same way every time you go to the gym, your body tends to adapt.
 
Even though it’s generally good to change your routine every 4 to 6 weeks, you can change your routine any time any of the exercises become boring. New exercises present new challenges.
 
You should come out of the gym energized and stimulated. If you find you are not as energized as you were before, substitute new exercises.
 
Talk to your gym about these six elements you need to keep yourself fit and establish your routine and change exercises every 4 to 6 weeks.
 
A workout buddy is also helpful to keep you motivated.

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article:
A2A. In my opinion, the best way to train for beginners and intermediates is 3–4 days a week, full-body. I train that way 95% of the time myself and I have been training for 14 years.
 
Note that this is the current trend in the newest and most cutting edge powerlifting training programs out there, Norwegian and RTS for example.
 
Advanced lifters who train 5–7 days a week, sometimes twice a day, may need to split their training up a little. They still squat, press and pull 3–7 days a week.
 
What is the problem with split training routines?
 
Let’s look at the concept. Basically the idea is that you trai
Continue Reading
A2A. In my opinion, the best way to train for beginners and intermediates is 3–4 days a week, full-body. I train that way 95% of the time myself and I have been training for 14 years.
 
Note that this is the current trend in the newest and most cutting edge powerlifting training programs out there, Norwegian and RTS for example.
 
Advanced lifters who train 5–7 days a week, sometimes twice a day, may need to split their training up a little. They still squat, press and pull 3–7 days a week.
 
What is the problem with split training routines?
 
Let’s look at the concept. Basically the idea is that you train a body part, say legs. once a week, completely into the ground, you “destroy”, “demolish”, “annihilate” your legs, then rest for a week.
 
Now, both research and experience has shown that first, most drug-free trainees cannot recover properly from such an extreme training session and that milder sessions spread out over the week work better and second, that the muscle building period after training in drug-free people is only 1–2 days and that they are then ready to train again.
 
In other words, you get much better results, at any stage of advancement, from squatting 3 sets Monday, 3 sets Wednesday and 3 sets Friday, than from squatting 9 sets Monday and resting for a week.
 
Not only that, but you avoid the crippling soreness that you get from once-a-week training and feel fresher and stronger all the time.
 
Yes, advanced trainees sometimes train for 5–10 sessions a week and then incorporate some sort of split, but they still work each basic movement several times during the week.
 
Whole-body does not imply that each session needs to be exactly the same. I keep them similar for total beginners. Repetition and practice in the base lifts is crucial. But for intermediates and above it is feasible and useful to vary the sessions, both the set/rep scheme and the exercise.

article:

Twenty years ago I was home from work sick, I mean REALLY sick so that I barely had enough energy to keep my eyes open. The TV was on and a really stupid game show called ‘The Newlywed Game’ came on. I wasn’t interested in it but couldn’t get together enough energy to get up to change the channel (this was before remotes).
 
The premise of the show was that they got newlyweds to show how much they knew about each other. First they sequestered the bride and asked the groom what he thought his wife would answer to a series of questions. Then they
Continue Reading
I didn’t exactly meet this person but saw them on TV.
 
Twenty years ago I was home from work sick, I mean REALLY sick so that I barely had enough energy to keep my eyes open. The TV was on and a really stupid game show called ‘The Newlywed Game’ came on. I wasn’t interested in it but couldn’t get together enough energy to get up to change the channel (this was before remotes).
 
The premise of the show was that they got newlyweds to show how much they knew about each other. First they sequestered the bride and asked the groom what he thought his wife would answer to a series of questions. Then they’d bring the bride out and see how well he knew what his new wife would answer.
 
One question that stuck in my mind was “How many states in America do you think your wife could name?”
 
The man’s answer was “5”.
 
The MC expressed some surprise that he thought his wife could only name 5 states and then went on to ask the rest of the questions.
 
Then it was the wife’s turn to answer the questions. She said “2”.
 
The MC started to go to the next question but couldn’t help himself. He had to go back and ask her if she was sure she could only name two states.
 
When she confirmed that was all she knew he asked her which two states she could name.
 
The answer? “California, and Mexico.”
 
She probably knew California because that was the state the show was filmed in and that’s where she lived. Then she got her second one wrong, naming a neighbouring country instead.
 
I found that amazing. I can not only name all 50 states, but with a blank piece of paper I could draw a map of the U.S. and include all the states and probably a good approximation of their boundaries - and I’m not even American. Do they even teac geography there?

title: What happens if you workout every day?
article:
The answer is yes you can.
 
Isometric training is how. You contract muscles but don’t move your joints.
 
This sort of training is especially recommended to people after joint surgeries to maintain and/or rebuilt their muscles. For instance, people after knee surgeries are exercising their quadriceps muscles by simple contractions of the said muscle. Their knees are fully extended and they perform and/or hold contractions.
 
It’s not perfect as they need to exercise in that way much longer compared with someone who would do a couple of squads but it’s nonetheless effective in maintaining and rebuildin
Continue Reading
The answer is yes you can.
 
Isometric training is how. You contract muscles but don’t move your joints.
 
This sort of training is especially recommended to people after joint surgeries to maintain and/or rebuilt their muscles. For instance, people after knee surgeries are exercising their quadriceps muscles by simple contractions of the said muscle. Their knees are fully extended and they perform and/or hold contractions.
 
It’s not perfect as they need to exercise in that way much longer compared with someone who would do a couple of squads but it’s nonetheless effective in maintaining and rebuilding musculature.
 
Also, the progression is rather limited. Training your muscles in this way will shape them and make them generally stronger, but training isn’t all about strength and endurance. It’s also about function, coordination and multi-joint activation. Isometric exercise won’t make you much more functional per se.
 
However since you asked only about getting muscles the answer is yes it is possible to get toned and strong muscles without any resistance training.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
It entirely depends on what you're trying to accomplish.
 
Are you trying to lose weight, or are you trying to build muscle ? Both at the same time is going to be extremely difficult if you only go to the gym once per week.
 
Other answers say high weight, low reps for once a week, but not only is this geared more towards a mass build than a weight loss/tone, but also can be unnecessarily dangerous to the joints of you're only doing it once a week.
 
I would recommend a treadmill or eliptical set before lifting. Then high reps with low weight when you lift, or a warm-up set on every specific exercise b
Continue Reading
It entirely depends on what you're trying to accomplish.
 
Are you trying to lose weight, or are you trying to build muscle ? Both at the same time is going to be extremely difficult if you only go to the gym once per week.
 
Other answers say high weight, low reps for once a week, but not only is this geared more towards a mass build than a weight loss/tone, but also can be unnecessarily dangerous to the joints of you're only doing it once a week.
 
I would recommend a treadmill or eliptical set before lifting. Then high reps with low weight when you lift, or a warm-up set on every specific exercise before you do your actual sets, followed with descending weight sets.
 
And remember that diet is key — if you don't keep a proper diet, the gym will not help you with anything you're trying to accomplish.

Long time ago, during nineties, while discussing on some internet board (forum) about who knows what (after 20 years i completely forgot) i got into a disagreement with one American fellow. It is important to mention he knew I am from eastern Europe and I knew he is from USA, Boston.
 
Well, this guy had arguments that were quite low, and mine were a bit stronger. He was pissed because of it and tried to discredit me by saying that I am not a competent for this argument at all, and my voice should not be heard considering my English mistakes (i was in high school at the time, having English as my third or fourth learning language by importance, and had only year or two of learning the language).
 
After a facepalm moment, I asked the guy politely, does he realize English is not my native language, and he got completely confused. As it happens, this guy knew there are some other languages in the world (he was learning French at the time also), but somehow supposed that all people in the world speak English as native language, and other languages are just 
“something from the past we keep like a tradition so it wouldn't be forgotten”
.
 
When I explained to him and he realized how wrong he was (i bet he had a facepalm moment also), he just left conversation and disappeared completely from the board :)
 
Something to add: I’ve read quite a lot of answers on this question and i really have to say i can not imagine how can people think like this and what the hell is going on with them. It’s quite a mystery to me. I’m 36 years old, lived in several cities and villages in my country and some nearby, and never had even one situation in those countries that could compete with the level of ignorance we read on these answers. I’ve met low educated and unintelligent people like everyone else, but people like from these answers here… complete mystery to me! This even more surprise me when we do know many, many extremely intelligent people from USA.

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
It is generally recommended that adults should aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous aerobic exercise per week, in addition to strength training exercises that work all major muscle groups at least two days per week.
 
However, if you are new to exercise or have been inactive for a while, it's important to start slow and gradually increase the frequency and intensity of your workouts over time. Consult with a healthcare professional or a fitness trainer for personalized recommendations based on your individual needs and goals. Remember, consistency is
Continue Reading
It is generally recommended that adults should aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate aerobic exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous aerobic exercise per week, in addition to strength training exercises that work all major muscle groups at least two days per week.
 
However, if you are new to exercise or have been inactive for a while, it's important to start slow and gradually increase the frequency and intensity of your workouts over time. Consult with a healthcare professional or a fitness trainer for personalized recommendations based on your individual needs and goals. Remember, consistency is key when it comes to achieving fitness goals, so finding a routine that you enjoy and can stick with long-term is important.

I'm not sure what is your definition of perfect body but I will share the exercises that helped me improve my fitness to get in best shape of my life till now. As requested, here are my before & after pictures:
 
Before Transformation (100 kgs at 5′8″)
After Transformation
 
(72 kgs at 5′8″)
It took me two and half years to achieve this transformation. I couldn't afford a personal trainer and I also wanted to know everything about fitness so that I can keep myself fit for lifelong without becoming too much dependent on others. So, I read and learned everything I could about various kinds of exercises & diets. I experimented with various split & full body routines. I tried various kinds of diets such as ketogenic & carb-cycling. I achived different level of results with all.
 
So, based on my experience, I can tell you that there are many ways to achieve the transformation you want but you can't and shouldn't limit yourself to just three exercises. That's why I am including more than three exercises, but only those that are the best. If you can create a program around these
 
ten exercises, you will be making good progress :
Barbell Back Squat : 
It's
 
the best exercise for your lower body. If done in correct form, and if you go below parallel, it will work not only your quads but also hamstrings, glutes and core.
Deadlift
 
: 
Along with squats, deadlift is one of the best exercise to build overall mass and strength. It targets your posterior chain including hamstring, glutes, erector spine & lats. Your core gets a good workout and it also improves your grip strength & forearm size.
Standing Calves Raise
 
: 
I do it on smith machine standing on step board. It's best for calves.
Flat & Inclined
 
Bench Press : 
Best exercise for chest but also works your anterior deltoids(front shoulders) and triceps. You can also do pushups for same effect but you won't be able to use as much weight as in bench press.
Military Press : 
Best exercise to target shoulder.
Bent Over Barbell Rows : 
Good exercise for lats, middle back, biceps & core.
Pull Ups & Chin Ups
 :
 
Best exercise for lats & biceps.
Parallel Bar Dips
 : Best for triceps.
HIIT : 
For cardiovascular health & fat loss. Sprint for 30 seconds and then walk for 30 seconds. Repeat for total 15 to 20 mins.
Yoga Poses : 
For flexibility & proper alignment of body.
P.S. : I know Yoga is not a single exercise but I included it to put emphasis on importance of flexibility & mobility work. Other kinds of flexibility & mobility routines will work too.

Dinosaur
Continue Reading
Hello,
 
I wouldn't call myself a workout “expert” per say but I am a fitness addict. This addiction started at the age of 13 when my father bought me my first weight set. I am currently 21 years old. In the 8 years that I have spent training, I've read dozens of books regarding training, read and watched thousands of videos in that time aswell.
Here an some interesting facts about myself:
 
I’ve performed over a million push-ups in my life.
Back to your question about two days a week full body workout. Here's a excerpt from the book 
Dinosaur Training: LOST SECRETS OF STRENGTH AND DEVELOPMENT.
Dinosaur training sessions are short, hard and infrequent. A typical session will consist of no more than twenty sets, with at least half of those sets being progressively heavier warm-ups. The average number of sets per workout would be between eight and fifteen. Some sessions will consist of only four or five sets. A typical week will see the dinosaur training only two or three times. That means the dinosaur trains his entire body with well under fifty sets PER WEEK. It also means the dinosaur will spend no more than three hours per week on his training. I refer to this type of training as abbreviated training.
 
There are two basic ways to implement abbreviated training. One way is to work the entire body in each workout. For example, you might train on Monday and Thursday. On Monday you would do squats, benches, pulldowns and seated military presses. On Thursday you would do HAMMER STRENGTH leg presses, stiff legged deadlifts, chins, dips and standing curls with a barbell. Thus, you are doing a total body workout every time you train, but you are doing different movements in each session and only working each particular exercise one time per week.
 
The second way to implement abbreviated training is to train each basic exercise only one time per week. and do only two or three basic exercises per session. For example, you might do squats and benches on Monday, followed by presses, pulldowns and dips on Wednesday, followed by deadlifts or cleans, shrugs and barrel lifting on Friday.
 
In either approach, the sets, reps and exercises are up to the discretion and personal preference of the lifter. Either system allows you to do high rep death marches with a heavy poundage ... to do five sets of five reps ... to do heavy singles ... to do rack work or anything else that strikes your fancy.
 
If you prefer to get more rest between training sessions, schedule your program over a ten day or two week period. For example, take two workouts over a ten day period instead of two workouts over a seven day period. Or train three times in two weeks rather than three times in one week. The variations are endless.
Just to make things easier for you, here's a great schedule:
 
DAY ONE
 (sets x reps)
 
1. Squat 4x5
 2. Standing Press 4x5
 3. Bent-over Barbell Row 4x5
 4. Farmer's Walk (one time)
 5. Bent-legged situps 2x8-15
 6. Auxiliary work for neck, biceps or calves (optional)
 
DAY TWO
 
1. Bent-legged Deadlift, Stiff-legged Deadlift, Power Clean, Power Pull, or Power Snatch 4 x 5 (or 5 x 3 for cleans, pulls or snatches)
 2. Bench Press (barbell or dumbbell) (or floor press) 4x5
 3. Sandbag Walk (one time)
 
4. Side-bends 2x8-15
 5. Auxiliary work as on Day One (optional)
 
Sounds simple, doesn't it? That's because it IS simple. Hard? Just try it.
 
Perseverance, patience and determination will be repaid in untold wealth, health, strength, self-reliance and fortitude. 
George F. Jowett

article:

She then also wanted to see Paris. So we took her there, the Eiffel Tower, the Arc de Triomphe, the Louvre… Then suddenly she said:
 
“We've been walking in Paris all day and I still haven't seen a cool guy.”
 
Apparently she had the idea that all Frenchmen were stunning Latin-lover-gigolos and she was disappointed.

title: How should my weekly gym workout be?
article:

Legs for Strength: the big compound lifts for 5 sets of 3-5 reps each.
 
Push for strength: low reps, big compound push movements.
 
Pull Strength:  low reps, compound pull movements
 
Rest / HIIT / Abs
 
Legs Hypertrophy: 8 to 12 reps with compound and isolation exercises

Oh My! This is such a sad list of answers. The answers are sad. The length of the list is sad. Here’s a couple more:
 
1). Riding in a car on a road that paralleled a Florida beach, we were driving in and out of patches of fog. The girl in the front seat seemed to be uneasy about the fog and exclaimed that she wished “It would go away”. … a few moments of silent agreement, then the driver spoke: “Hey Susie, did you know that fog is just a cloud that’s developed on the ground?” [I thought it was a joke question] …a few more moments of silence, then: “Nuh uh! …Clouds are millions and millions of miles away!”
 
2) At a diner, I was exchanging small-talk with a young lady who suddenly blurted that she quit her job that afternoon. Of course, thinking there was a backstory to the statement, I asked why. Her answer:
 
“Well, I was thinking… I have bills and I’m working. If I quit working, I’m still going to have bills; so what’s the point?”
 
The reason I didn’t try to reason this out with her wasn’t because I was flabbergasted (I was), but rather because of the obvious pride she exhibited for this stroke of glorious insight. She was a nurse! …True Story!

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
In 1974 I was travelling by myself in the US. I’d just graduated high school and treated my self to a long vacation in the US before coming back to begin my three year military service.
 
While on a train from LA to San Francisco, I got into a conversation with what seemed to be a reasonably normal family. When I told them that I was from Israel, and could visit Jerusalem whenever I wanted to, and could speak read and write Hebrew. Then they asked me something about Jesus, and could I speak the same language he did. I told them yes, but like most Israelis, I’m Jewish. This floored them, apparentl
Continue Reading
In 1974 I was travelling by myself in the US. I’d just graduated high school and treated my self to a long vacation in the US before coming back to begin my three year military service.
 
While on a train from LA to San Francisco, I got into a conversation with what seemed to be a reasonably normal family. When I told them that I was from Israel, and could visit Jerusalem whenever I wanted to, and could speak read and write Hebrew. Then they asked me something about Jesus, and could I speak the same language he did. I told them yes, but like most Israelis, I’m Jewish. This floored them, apparently these guys had never met a Jew before. One of the kids, a 10 or 12 year old, kept looking at me and whispered something to her mother. The mother than asks me would I mind if her daughter could feel my horns. It was clear there was no malice involved, just boundless ignorance. I explained to her that no, we do not have horns, so there is nothing to feel.
 
As a former South African, I’ve also had the pleasure of been asked by Americans how come I’m not Black if I’m from Africa, and was it dangerous there because of all the lions everywhere.
 
Even my American wife, who is reasonably intelligent, and well educated (degrees from two good colleges a notch below the Ivy League), and grew up in a upper middle class family who lived in a fairly affluent neighborhood of a large and sophisticated city (NY) can sometimes surprise me with flashes of ignorance. Several times I’ve had to correct her about American history. Clearly American education is in a bad way.

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
Ideally, should not do strength training (ST) every day. You should have mix of ST, Cardio, Cardiovascular, Yoga, core and Pranayam sessions.
 
If you want to focus only on ST, then, it should be divided as per following-
 
CST- Chest, Shoulders, Triceps - One session a day
 
BB- Back and Biceps - One session a day
 
Legs - One session a day
 
And then you can repeat the same sequence again.
 
Hope it helps.

I usually eat one big meal a day or 2 medium meals. I love a bargain and frankly won't buy anything unless it's half price, reduced or buy-one-get-one-free. ALDI is near mine and under £20 can last my family a fortnight (2week).
 
I pay the wifi and that's it. I also help out with the gas and electric.
 
I got my forklift licence through welfare, I have worked in factories. 12 hours, weekends, nights, you name it.
 
I'm currently working as a labourer in NE London, I get a ride there Monday 3am and return home Friday 2pm. I get free accommodation and some free food. The money is good but I must wait as it is fortnightly pay.
 
I know the value of money. I know what I want to do with my life. I'm just a simple guy, I don't stop for anything because I don't want to be like this forever.
 
You have to be an opportunist in this life.
 
Keep winning

article:
I have a friend from California. Not the ignorant type at all, honestly. But she does not know a thing about Canada. Nothing. When I asked her to name the provinces of Canada, she came up with Ontario, Quebec, Montreal, Saskatoon, and something like Watasatchewan. I also was having a discussion with her about universities, and when discussing the possibility of me attending the University of Victoria, she asked where it was located. Logically it’s in Victoria. But she had no clue. So I led her on. Told her it was in the middle of the Northwest Territories. Accessibly only by ice road. And she 
Continue Reading
I have a friend from California. Not the ignorant type at all, honestly. But she does not know a thing about Canada. Nothing. When I asked her to name the provinces of Canada, she came up with Ontario, Quebec, Montreal, Saskatoon, and something like Watasatchewan. I also was having a discussion with her about universities, and when discussing the possibility of me attending the University of Victoria, she asked where it was located. Logically it’s in Victoria. But she had no clue. So I led her on. Told her it was in the middle of the Northwest Territories. Accessibly only by ice road. And she believed me. She said it was sad how isolated it must be for people who attended it. She only started doubting when I told her there were polar bear races there.
 
She’s also a serious football fan, but had never heard of the Canadian Football League or the Grey Cup, one of the oldest pro sports trophies in North America. The existence of football in Canada shocked her, but she also thought Canadians didn’t watch the Super Bowl. She’s a great friend, but the ignorance about Canada always makes me laugh.

Either way, I guess its pretty much ignorant. But cute ignorance if you ask me.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
My number one recommendation:
 
1- Spend more time a standing up
 
Depending on what your job is, most people tend to spend a lot more time sitting down than is recommended. Not only does it promote a sedentary routine, it is also terrible for your posture as the muscles required for healthy core are not as active, therefore will atrophy at a faster than ideal rate. If you can stand up for a greater portion of your day compared to sitting (whilst keeping focus on a good posture as much as possible) it will set you up for a much more active lifestyle without having to completely change your routine. 
Continue Reading
My number one recommendation:
 
1- Spend more time a standing up
 
Depending on what your job is, most people tend to spend a lot more time sitting down than is recommended. Not only does it promote a sedentary routine, it is also terrible for your posture as the muscles required for healthy core are not as active, therefore will atrophy at a faster than ideal rate. If you can stand up for a greater portion of your day compared to sitting (whilst keeping focus on a good posture as much as possible) it will set you up for a much more active lifestyle without having to completely change your routine. Things like changing to a stand-up desk, parking further away to add a couple of minutes for a quick walk in between errands, anything you can think of to get you off your butt throughout the day will help to transform your life easily. On top of this, burpees are a fantastic way to start the day, it activates most of the major muscle groups and doesn’t require any special equipment

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:
I hate to answer a question with a question, but I have to in this scenario: 
which routine are you actually going to stick with?
 
In undergrad, I did bro splits because 1) I went to the gym with my roommate and he did bro splits and 2) I was a college kid and had a lot of time on my hands. I could get to the gym five days a week because it was right there on campus; I had nothing else to worry about aside from classes.
 
I took about a decade off from the gym (let’s say from 2009 to 2017) and when I found my way back, I was thirty with a full-time job - I didn’t have the same amount of time to play
Continue Reading
I hate to answer a question with a question, but I have to in this scenario: 
which routine are you actually going to stick with?
 
In undergrad, I did bro splits because 1) I went to the gym with my roommate and he did bro splits and 2) I was a college kid and had a lot of time on my hands. I could get to the gym five days a week because it was right there on campus; I had nothing else to worry about aside from classes.
 
I took about a decade off from the gym (let’s say from 2009 to 2017) and when I found my way back, I was thirty with a full-time job - I didn’t have the same amount of time to play with. I opted to go with a push-pull-legs split - I figured I could at least get three days in. Ideally, it would have looked like this:
But a funny thing happened: if I had any kind of conflict at all, I skipped leg day. Board meeting runs late? Skip leg day. Get in an argument with my girlfriend? Skip leg day. Looks like rain outside? You get the idea. No excuse was too trivial.
 
Eventually, I realized that “leg day” - devoting an entire workout session to some of the most taxing exercises you can do - was psychologically overwhelming. So I moved to total body because it ensured that I worked legs and worked with my schedule. Yes, I still had to do squats and deadlifts, but 1) I didn’t have to do them on the same day and 2) I got to follow them up with what I like to call “dessert” exercises - curls, triceps pushdowns, etc.
 
However, just because total body works for me doesn’t mean it’s the best option for you. You know your schedule better than I do. And, more importantly, you know yourself - your tendencies, your weak areas, etc. Take all of that knowledge into consideration and then choose the option that works best for you.
