This was a few years ago. I am an American. I was at a store and had bought a gift for a friend and wanted it sent to her. Gave the clerk the address and she said they couldn’t ship it to the address I gave her. When I asked her why, she said they didn’t ship out of the United States. 
I looked at her and asked to speak to the manager. The manager comes over, I explain that I want the item shipped to my friend at this address, but the sales lady said it couldn’t be shipped there. The manager looked at it and said, “No we don’t ship outside the United States”. 
The manager, a man, and the sales lady, were both in their 50’s, or so.
 
I was wanting to ship to an address in NEW MEXICO, from COLORADO. The two states are literally next door to each other.
 
When I explained that New Mexico was part of the US and just south of Colorado, the manager said he was from back East, so how should he know?
 
I told him he was a freaking US Citizen, he should know. The sales lady then asked if my friend spoke English. 🤦🏼‍♀️ 
 
I told them to forget the sale, I wanted my money back. I then left.
 
This was a chain clothing store. I sent a letter to the main office, but never heard back from anyone.

title: Is a morning gym workout better than an evening gym workout?
article:
In a second, I’m going to paint you a picture of what it is like working out in the morning and what it’s like working out in the evening.
 
But before that, let me say that I do both.
 
Sometimes, like this morning, I’ll get up at the crack of dawn and hit the gym.
 
Other times, I go to work and look forward to lifting weights right after.
 
It just depends on what I want to do that day.
 
Both have pros and both have cons, it’s up to you to decide what makes sense for you.
 
MORNING WORKOUT
 
Your alarm clock goes off and you wake up, it’s very early.
 
You have a small mental battle about getting out of bed but s
Continue Reading
In a second, I’m going to paint you a picture of what it is like working out in the morning and what it’s like working out in the evening.
 
But before that, let me say that I do both.
 
Sometimes, like this morning, I’ll get up at the crack of dawn and hit the gym.
 
Other times, I go to work and look forward to lifting weights right after.
 
It just depends on what I want to do that day.
 
Both have pros and both have cons, it’s up to you to decide what makes sense for you.
 
MORNING WORKOUT
 
Your alarm clock goes off and you wake up, it’s very early.
 
You have a small mental battle about getting out of bed but see your workout clothes laid out on the ground from the night before. You would feel so lazy to skip the gym and put those clothes back in the drawer, so you get up, grab your gym bag, pour a much needed coffee, and head out the door.
 
The ride to the gym is peaceful. The world is still asleep, the sun is still down, and you own the road.
 
You walk in the gym, a little more energized but still stiff. You’re already here so you might as well get started with some warmups.
 
The gym is practically empty and all the equipment is available. You pick your first exercise and begin.
 
Before you know it, the initial sleepiness has drifted away and been replaced with a fresh dose of energy.
 
You get in the zone, start sweating, and feel your heart pounding as you crush your workout.
 
Forty-five minutes later and you are done. You shower and step out of the gym heading for your car. You remember that the rest of the world is just waking up.
The sun is peaking out, the birds are stretching their wings, and the air is filled with slightly more activity than when you first got there.
 
You drive to work feeling energized, knowing that you’ve already conquered the day and improved yourself. Regardless of how the rest of the day goes, you know deep down that you already won.
 
To top if off, your mind is ready to get to work and you feel free knowing that your evening is completely open.
 
This, is the feeling of working out in the morning.
 
EVENING WORKOUT
 
The evening workout has a completely different vibe.
 
You wake up at a normal time and head to work with everyone else.
 
As the work day starts winding down, you begin thinking about your workout.
 
If you’ve eaten healthy during the day, you’re energized and ready to get in there and crush it.
 
If you haven’t eaten healthy, you feel sleepiness slowly creeping in.
 
Either way, you snag a coffee and leave, happy that the work day is over.
 
As you sip on your coffee, and listen to your pre-gym music in your car, you start feeling more excited about the gym.
 
You’re either happy to be able to leave the stress of work behind you or eager to get to the weights and lift the stress away.
 
Unlike the morning, you get to the gym and your body and mind are already awake. However, the gym is more crowded at this time of day and you have to strategically pick which exercise to start with.
 
You put your headphones in, find an empty machine, and get to work.
 
The right song comes on, you start sweating, and you feel your heart pounding as you crush your workout.
 
An hour and fifteen minutes later (due to some waiting for machines) you finish up and head for the door. You step out of the gym and head for your car, realizing that the sun is starting to lower on the horizon.
You head home feeling pumped that you conquered the day and improved yourself. The day is almost over, but you still have a couple hours to eat, shower, and do whatever you please.
 
This, is the feeling of working out in the evening.
Which is better?
 
I can’t make that decision for you.
 
Test them both out and see what fits your lifestyle.
 
At the end of the day, the best time to work out is the one that you actually stick to.

title: Can I do a light workout every day?
article:
As with all fitness questions, it depends.
 
There are two conditions that I’ll put on a “yes” answer:
You’re not pushing yourself at an extreme level (keeping it under 80% intensity)
You still take a rest day every microcycle (every 1–2 weeks).
If you work out 
hard
 every day your body won’t rebuild and metabolic fatigue will set in quickly (it’ll set in if you work daily, also even where your workout is >50% <80%). You could set experience 
overtraining syndrome
, where your body cannot recover enough between workouts.
 
Additionally, your body requires a certain amount of time to recover between workou
Continue Reading
As with all fitness questions, it depends.
 
There are two conditions that I’ll put on a “yes” answer:
You’re not pushing yourself at an extreme level (keeping it under 80% intensity)
You still take a rest day every microcycle (every 1–2 weeks).
If you work out 
hard
 every day your body won’t rebuild and metabolic fatigue will set in quickly (it’ll set in if you work daily, also even where your workout is >50% <80%). You could set experience 
overtraining syndrome
, where your body cannot recover enough between workouts.
 
Additionally, your body requires a certain amount of time to recover between workouts. If you’re providing enough stimulus to your muscles this is usually between 36 and 48 hours (
depending on the muscle worked (muscles like your core tend to recover faster
), your gender (
women tend to recover faster than men)
, the intensity that you worked the muscle (
the harder you worked it the longer it will take)
, your age (
over 60 you will require as much as 96 hours rest to recover between workouts), 
the nutrition applied, and your hormone profile (
more testosterone, HGH, IGF will lead to quicker recovery when coupled with adequate amounts of protein and glucose
)).
If you don’t give it enough time, you won’t build up past your initial baseline, and your muscles will suffer.
 
As metabolic fatigue builds up, even in lighter intensity training, you’ll feel it all over. It could be something simple at first — you stop improving in your lifts, for example. Eventually you start getting worse. Soon you start getting injuries that aren’t healing. You start to feel depressed. Even one day off with complete relaxation or even a light walk could be enough to clear you out, if you catch it early enough. Serious cases of overtraining could require more time.
 
To re-iterate:
If you don’t work it over 80% intensity every day
If you 
do
 take a break once every 1–2 weeks
You’ll be fine.
 
If you notice things going wrong — you start feeling weaker, you stop improving, you start feeling like crap in general, you start getting injuries…take a step back. Rest. Recover.
Brief anecdote as illustration
 
Once I was really working my pull ups. I was stuck at 18. I would do them daily, at least 4 sets. I hit 18 every time in my first set, I ended up doing about 50 a day. At first I was gaining daily, I went from 8 to 10 to 14, to 18…but then the growth stopped. I was stuck there for a couple weeks.
 
I took 2 days off from doing pull ups.
 
The next time I stepped up to the bar I did 25 in my first set.
 
I’m not saying that you’ll have dramatic results like this, but sometimes the missing part of your workout is actually 
not
 working out.

Although I had read about overtraining and it's cons but I continued. I was missing the peace of mind and felt weakness because of aggressive training. Maybe because my body was not able to adapt considering I have a desk job.
 
I started taking a day off and later found the ideal split with 2 days off in a week gave some serious results. I feel more strength an

Anything in excess is bad but exceptions exists too.
Personally having trained for 7 days a week for few months did not help with muscle recovery. I was so obsessed that I stopped caring for results and blindly lifted heavy weights daily . Although I had read about overtraining and it's cons but I continued. I was missing the peace of mind and felt weakness because of aggressive training. Maybe because my body was not able to adapt considering I have a desk job.
 
I started taking a day off and later found the ideal split with 2 days off in a week gave some serious results. I feel more strength and hungrier to lift than before.
 
So if I were to recommend then 4–5 days per week is healthy and good. Few pointers:
Choosing rest days is important too. I always prefer a day off after legs day.
Try avoiding rest for 2 days consecutively. It depends on your workout intensity too.

Weight bearing activity across the board has benefits no question, but the answers given all deal with ego not exercise.
 
One of the best exercise’s is swimming. It takes breathing control, works range of motion, is the perfect complement to weight bearing activity
There are less shearing forces on the joints, less biomechanical facets to consider, and the heart lungs and limbs create an inter muscular environment that’s

Wow! This question has most of the respondents in tunnel vision. I do not take the question as the holy grail of lifting weights, I look at the question as total body proficiency.
 
Weight bearing activity across the board has benefits no question, but the answers given all deal with ego not exercise.
 
One of the best exercise’s is swimming. It takes breathing control, works range of motion, is the perfect complement to weight bearing activity
There are less shearing forces on the joints, less biomechanical facets to consider, and the heart lungs and limbs create an inter muscular environment that’s more complete than just throwing around plate.
 
Most lifters have muscles due to vanity training but are dead out of shape because their mind set is about what the muscle looks like on land and in the eyes of their peers.
 
Bret Cantreras work while noteworthy has not moved the industry forward nor armed the masses with anything but load bearing on a boney hip structures for glutes which can be done way more completely than loading the pelvis when its not even a hinged joint. OH WELL!
 
Squats or squat Lunge combination: There are 4 weight bearing activities that work 33% of all the muscles in the body. 
Squats, Lunges, Power cleans. and dead lifts - thats 33% for each exercise type.
I’ve misplaced the referencing link for researching it your self.. but these exercises use the most proprioception, over the greatest variety of execution and total range in conjunction to plane of motion muscles than pullups than other exercise mentioned in this post.
 
Another huge quality of Squats or squat lunge combination are your bodies pich points where the fluids coursing through your arteries veins and capillaries are momentarily pinched ie pressurized causing blood flow to vascularize and expand all of your internal organs - conditioning them as well..
 
This concept is one of the most missed areas of fitness by so called Gurus, celebrity trainers and fitness researchers of muscle performance.
 
Lastly I see Plyometrics and Par Kour as a tie for the third best exercise..
Neither require you to be a weight head who only see fitness as skin deep..
 
Par Kour requires an ever evolving skill and no matter what level you achieve it will give you a work out because of the direct changes your body is forced to adapt just to be able to do the basics.. and if you learn this with weights then bam you get both the fitness and the physical proficiency of being in shape.
 
Plyo metrics shakes things up alot. The weight of the fluid in your body will conditioning you. Think of plyometrics as calisthenics that will take your bretah away every time and all the time..It’s exercising at your muscles legal limit.
 
These exercises have nothing to do with staying clear of injury’s as any exercise if there is an error in calculating your ability will cause injury.. So the guy who crying foul about injury should be kicked out of fitness period and head to the rehab facilities because you cant get fit be fit or stay fit the way he his mindset be training you. He’s stuck at wanting a doctor credential not a advancing the needs of the client.
 
With any of these three exercises if you add Exercise Short Codes.. your fitness will be sustainable the best for the rest of your life.. As you can get better withn age
 
Author of The Non Exercise’s Guide to Nourishing Your Soul’s Journey

I haven’t met Trump yet but when I do he will be.
 
I can however give you details of the most ignorant family to visit the United States (in the late 1979s). They visited a motel whilst driving through Florida. The son chatted with a nice local lady in the bar and totally failed to realise that she was amorously interested in him, his parents were astounded when he returned to the family room as they had not expected to see him till the next morning. The parents went on to visit friends in Washington DC. One of the days their hosts got called out for a work emergency and left them to their own devices. They went out for a walk of about three miles and found a street market, they had a marvellous time shopping and talking with the locals. When they told their hosts about it they blanched “whites don’t go in that part of town and the police only go in in large groups!”. It was my family, my ignorance of American mores cost me a holiday romance, my parents ignorance saved them from hostility in the hood because they were friendly and not afraid.

title: What are the dirtiest songs you've ever heard?
article:
I’ll go back a bit to the 20’s, 30’s, and 40’s (1920’s, that is, not the 2020’s). And I’ll go to the blues. Pulling out just 2 of my CDs (Copulatin’ Blues volumes 1 and 2). You can look up the lyrics to any of these, and I’m just giving a small set.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I didn't meet but saw on TV a few years ago. The small details of the show are sketchy but makes no difference to the outcome.
 
It was one of those documentaries talking about a place in an African country. It was showing the different animals and how they come close to a particular building where tourists visited.
 
One scene showed a couple of middle-aged women looking out a first floor window of a building to the platform (like an unfenced deck) below. A mongoose had made it's way onto it. One of the women said (in her drawl), “Is that a rat?”

article:

The thing that amused me was that he kept shouting about his ‘constitutional rights.’
 
Er, you're in Malaysia and if you don't reel it in you're possibly going to be spending the night in a Malaysian jail cell. This isn't your country and they do things a little differently here.

I don't think this counts as one an ignorant “American” necessarily, but it really bothered me so… Today I saw a woman who had just finished shopping. Trying to find the shortest possible route to her car she, with much difficulty, squeezed through tightly packed cars with her cart. She scraped a couple cars in the process, but continued to walk; Didn't change route so that she wouldn't affect any other cars, she just kept walking. She arrived at her car, the one adjacent to the one I was sitting in and unloaded her purchases. She continues to take the, now empty cart, and pushes it forward. I think, “Good, at least she's gonna put it back where she got it from”, but no. She puts it in front of her car, despite the place to put carts is literally five steps away. She sits back in her car and sits there for five minutes, browsing on her phone. I could not believe that she wouldn't have the common decency to put the cart back where she got it. Seriously, all she had to take was five steps and she could've saved someone's car from getting scratched. Sometimes it's the small things that can prove what type of person someone is. (I was gonna put the cart away myself, but someone had already done it by the time I got out of the car)

title: Is running every day better than going to the gym every day?
article: Well it depends. Just to stay you can choose any one of them. Running or any cardio workout will help in improving cardiovascular endurance. Whereas weight training in the gym will help you build muscular strength and endurance. So combining both of them in your lifestyle is a better option in my opinion. It will help you get better body composition. Some people do cardio and weight training on alternate days in a week. So do whatever option suits you as per your goal.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
A US Coastguard Official…..
 
Circa 2003. In the aftermath of 9/11, Homeland Security Department was expanding exponentially. I was a young 2nd Mate on a cargo ship carrying liquefied gas. It wasn't the best time to be a 20 something, brown skin south Asian male in the US, but that is a story for another time.
 
US Coastguard had expanded their security role significantly to inspect all incoming ships. Naturally, lot of rather inexperienced people were recruited, or pushed through the ranks.
 
In Houston, we were ‘hosting’ a team of USCG personnel, who insisted upon checking the whole vessel armed with
Continue Reading
A US Coastguard Official…..
 
Circa 2003. In the aftermath of 9/11, Homeland Security Department was expanding exponentially. I was a young 2nd Mate on a cargo ship carrying liquefied gas. It wasn't the best time to be a 20 something, brown skin south Asian male in the US, but that is a story for another time.
 
US Coastguard had expanded their security role significantly to inspect all incoming ships. Naturally, lot of rather inexperienced people were recruited, or pushed through the ranks.
 
In Houston, we were ‘hosting’ a team of USCG personnel, who insisted upon checking the whole vessel armed with scary looking weapons, ammo good to go.
 
The Captain's feeble attempts at explaining that it wasn't a good idea to consider firing a round while you were aboard a ship loaded with 30 thousand tons of highly explosive propane was met with general derision from the ‘protectors of American way of life'!!
 
Anyway, I got tasked with accompanying the team inspecting the deck area. The 3 ‘coasties' were most interested in ascertaining if I was an Arab. That out of the way, they thawed a bit (I am not Arab, incidentally). The least hostile one then decided to ask me the question I shall never forget.
 
“So Mr. Mate, tell me which is the farthest place you have ever been to?”. My jaw dropped! Was he kidding?! No, not at all. An answer was expected of me.
 
“From where?” I ask. Now the coastie is already a bit confused. “Er, you are Indian, right? So which is the farthest place from India you have been to?”
 
“Here. This place. Houston”, I tell him.
 
I shall never forget his face. Utter confusion written on it. “How can this be the farthest place from ANYWHERE? I mean this is Houston, right?! This IS the centre of the world!”
 
I had multiple experiences of similar kind. I was asked by one security personnel if I was Russian. And I am as Indian looking as is possible! He was friendly. But his ‘reason for asking' was that there was apparently an active Russian gang around that area indulging in stealing car stereos!! He was just ‘making sure'!
 
I am trying not to generalize. Maybe it had to do with the fact that I was a sailor on high risk ships. We met the same kind of security personnel every time we sailed into US. Calling US ports in those days would always leave a metallic taste in every sailor's mouth.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I am an Indian and I was traveling from Dallas, TX, USA to Singapore with a layover in Dubai, UAE. Emirates has this scheme if you have a layover of more than 8 hours in Dubai (Economy), you can get free hotel stay and UAE visa for the layover period. Presuming I would be severely jet-lagged I opted for it.
 
I was having lunch at the hotel and one of my co-passengers, who was a US citizen, asked me if she could join me. We were making small talks and she asked me what do I do. I told her I am a PhD student in Electrical Engineering in Singapore and I was in the US for a conference. We talked in 
Continue Reading
I am an Indian and I was traveling from Dallas, TX, USA to Singapore with a layover in Dubai, UAE. Emirates has this scheme if you have a layover of more than 8 hours in Dubai (Economy), you can get free hotel stay and UAE visa for the layover period. Presuming I would be severely jet-lagged I opted for it.
 
I was having lunch at the hotel and one of my co-passengers, who was a US citizen, asked me if she could join me. We were making small talks and she asked me what do I do. I told her I am a PhD student in Electrical Engineering in Singapore and I was in the US for a conference. We talked in general about places to see in Dubai, how electrical power is reliable in the US, and something about her mother’s town facing a power outage for two days because of some natural calamity.
 
After I came with a fresh plate of serving, she asks where I am from and what religion do I practice. I told her I am from India and am a Hindu. And then she asks, do I practice Voo-doo. I was flabbergasted and said no. Then she went on saying that she met an Indian once and that person practiced Voo-doo. I said it could be possible, it is a country of 1.25 billion people and some of them may practice Voo-doo. She seemed convinced that I was lying and not telling her about my Voo-doo sessions. By her body language and conversation, it seemed to me that she believed all Hindus practiced Voo-doo. I was quite taken aback by this whole conversation, but didn’t want to seem impolite and didn’t want to help her form another stereotype. After a few more bites, I said my good-byes to her and wished her well for her stay in Dubai.
 
This was in 2014 and the lady was college educated and lived in Dallas.

My turn to slow motion blink, “the 6 piece meal will do nicely thank you” I said inwardly shaking my head and paid.
 
Clearly very irritated with me by then she shoved the receipt at me, “why didn't you say so in the first place” she huffed
 
My boys meanwhile had been silently observing this exchange. The middle one piped up “she did!”
 
We took our lunch to go

Well , I have two examples.
 
First: Security officer in my office: once a friend, an ex colleague, who was my ride,came to my office. He wanted to use restroom and since he already worked there he knew that he needs a visitor pass to get in and the only way to get in is by invitation from an existing employee. Since he calls me by my middle name , which is common in India, he used my name as Chaitanya Kalavacharla and also called me downstairs. So when I went downstairs when this security officer asked my id and when I showed him my id , it says Krishna Kalavacharla. So, understanding his confusion, I showed him my drivers license which says “ Krishna Chaitanya Kalavacharla “. But like many people in this country he did not care to apply his brain and did not let my friend inside. Long story short, my friend moved onto a restaurant nearby!
 
Second: This is not with one person but with several Americans. I am Indian and of course I have Indian accent. What surprises me is Americans accept every accent from the world except Indian but I digress. I pronounce the word Mosquito as “muskito” and apparently American pronunciation is “muskeeeto” and it literally took me over 20 minutes to explain someone that mosquitoes breed in stagnant water! Before you judge me I speak flawless English and 6 other languages.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I've been asked all sorts of weird questions, having grown up in India…
 
“What did you do for entertainment?,” or “How did you spend weekends?”
 
At first, I used to get irritated, but then I used to say that I used to ride elephants into the jungle with my mates, and we'd hide out in trees and hunt panthers, etc. it got ridiculous after a while, and some people still believed it and didn't get the sarcasm.

title: How long will it take to get big if doing full body workouts every day with heavy weights?
article:
Results is a subjective term, but in my experience, you will at least feel results in about 2–3 weeks, and have noticeable improvement and gains in about 3 months.
 
Everyone’s genetics and workouts are different so your results and timing will vary.
 
My friendly piece of advice: make it a lifestyle choice to exercise, rather than using it as a one time or quick fix. Be consistent and make it a sustainable lifelong endeavor. At almost 60 year old, I will attest to its amazing benefits both physically and cognitively.

I agree, push, pull and squat combination provide you with a solid full body workout BUT what if you aren’t a gym member or don’t have excess to weights or a pull up bar, what will you do?
 
While push, pull, squat variations are perhaps THE exercises to go to, others, often neglected ones, might give you just as good as a workout.
 
Two exercises that come to mind that BOTH work FULL body, especially your core and balance are:
staggered get up (while holding a weight - even a household weight such as a jug of water- over your head)
roll up (if you have weights you can add chest press, pull over or overhead squat hold when rolling back up into a standing position)
Both exercises will work your legs, glutes, core and upper body strength. These are a bit different from the standard exercises but IF YOU ONLY engage in basic exercises you are missing out!
 
Change things up. You might be surprised just how challenging these are for you, especially the first one!

article:
The worst personal experience I had was actually in the UK.
 
Just after the 9/11 disaster I was in Birmingham for a broadcasting trade show. Our UK distributer had also some other technical people over from the US. When the show was finished we decided to take a cab to the airport together to limit costs.
 
Aside the first available taxi stood a guy looking a bit like this:
My American partner’s reaction was: “I’m not getting in his taxi, I don’t trust it. You know what happened in New York.”
 
I was a bit flabbergasted and told him: “But he is not an Arab. He’s a Sikh, from India. These people have no

The worst personal experience I had was actually in the UK.
 
Just after the 9/11 disaster I was in Birmingham for a broadcasting trade show. Our UK distributer had also some other technical people over from the US. When the show was finished we decided to take a cab to the airport together to limit costs.
 
Aside the first available taxi stood a guy looking a bit like this:
My American partner’s reaction was: “I’m not getting in his taxi, I don’t trust it. You know what happened in New York.”
 
I was a bit flabbergasted and told him: “But he is not an Arab. He’s a Sikh, from India. These people have nothing to do with that attack.”
 
But he could not accept that: “He’s wearing one of those turbans and he has a beard. How do you know that he’s not a terrorist?”
 
At a certain point I had to give up and accept that we would take another taxi. There was still a plane to catch.

title: What is the best workout routine to follow?
article: I do whatever I enjoy doing. When I do that I keep exercising and that's more important than anything else at my age. In the morning I jump for 15 minutes on a mini-trampoline. Mid-morning or early afternoon I do a 7 Minute Workout per an app on my cell phone. On Tuesdays and Thursdays I do yoga and lifting. Sometimes in the afternoon Monday through Friday I do some exercise/lifting in the exercise room in our building. In addition, I hike 6–8 miles in the mountains, rollerblade or dance at least once a week.

that I love to work out.  I know that once I get to the gym and get going that I 
always
 feel better after my work out.  So I know that if I go to the gym then I will be better off.  I just need to go even though

.
 
Secondly, I slept in my gym clothes.  Yup.  And I also kept my shoes, headphones and gym tag right next to my bed.
 
When I woke up 90% of the work was ALREADY done.   I didn't have to think about a single thing.  I knew where my headphones were.  I knew what outfit I wanted to wear.  I knew what I was doing once I got to the gym.
 
All I had to do was put on my shoes and go.  And I don't think there is anything easier than that.

Each week we got a new batch of scouts in, and while their leaders registered them, the staff did the swimming assessments for the kids down at the lake. In 2008 I was the international counselor at Many Point Scout Camp in Minnesota. Each week we got a new batch of scouts in, and while their leaders registered them, the staff did the swimming assessments for the kids down at the lake. We also did the introductions of our staff to them. Every time we did this, I wore a New Zealand sports team shirt (cricket) all with the words NEW ZEALAND on them, and large silver fern designs or similar on them.
 
We got into the habit early on that we would let the scouts guess where in the world I came from. Out of about 1500 kids over the summer, I think only about 3 got it right first time, and one impressed me because he got it from recognising the New Zealand flag up by the lodge.
 
Naturally I got told Australia more times than I could count, with a few “England”, “Scotland” and “Canada” respo...

title: How often should I workout for best results?
article:
It depends on your goal, intensity, training experience, and age. You can work out daily if you are taking one or 2 days off for rest and also you are not overtraining or with high intensity. If you are working out with high intensity then you need good rest to recover muscles. As you age your capacity to recover muscles reduce so you have to keep in mind your age .accroding to your age, you should train. If you are beginner then there might be chances that you won't be able to recover quickly as like experience people so you have to start slowly and increase your intensity.

If you are beginner then there might be chances that you won't be able to recover quickly as like experience people so you have to start slowly and increase your intensity.
 
Hope my answer helps you.
 
Thank you😇

title: What is a good at home workout routine for intermediate beginners?
article:
Something that works really well in your situation, is what I dubbed the “prison cell workout”
 
You literally need no equiptment other than a sturdy towell.
 
But what you do need, however, is a ton of cojones or ovaires (This is NOT for the casual “I just want to get in shape” dabbler…this is for people who are serious about making progress).
 
This type of workout looks really easy on paper, but will smoke even very strong people.

Continue Reading
Something that works really well in your situation, is what I dubbed the “prison cell workout”
 
You literally need no equiptment other than a sturdy towell.
 
But what you do need, however, is a ton of cojones or ovaires (This is NOT for the casual “I just want to get in shape” dabbler…this is for people who are serious about making progress).
 
This type of workout looks really easy on paper, but will smoke even very strong people.
 
I still use this once or twice a week to increase my work capactiy and pain threshold.
 
If you can get through this type of routine 3–5 times a week, there’s literally nothing that can stop you.
 
This is not only a workout for your physical body, but also for your mental and spiritual muscles.
 
Big words, I know, but try it and you’ll know what I’m talking about.
 
Here goes…
 
Get your smartphone. Or use your watch to stop the time (you’ll try to beat the time you recorded).
 
As soon as you hit “start” and the clock is ticking, you’ll perform 200 push-ups, 250 squats and 100 towell pullups as fast as possible (with excellent form, obviously).
 
Of course you shouldn’t bang out all 200 push-ups, 250 squats and 100 pullups all in one set!
 
Divide the work up, so that you DON’T go to muscular failure on each and every set! That’s really important, or else you’ll burn out.
 
What I do, for example, is that I do sets of 20 on push-up (so 10 sets per “round”), 25–50 reps on squats, 5–10 reps on pullups.
 
Find a set and rep scheme that works for you. Again, you SHOULD NOT go to muscular failure in each and ever set. Keep 2–3 reps in the tank.
 
With that said, the key do these type of workouts, is to rest as little as possible (remember you’re doing this for time).
 
I always hit a set of push-ups, immediately followed by a set of squats and then, without rest, I bang out my pullups. Then I’ll rest for 45–60sec. Only to start the next set.
 
Trust me, your heart rate will jack the heck up on this routine!
 
You don’t have to run any additional cardio with this and you’ll develop a very “functional” type of strength endurance if you stick to it.
 
Oh, and you’ll also build some lean muscle! Especially if you haven’t used these type of “prison cell workouts” in the past.
 
But make no mistake…This is not for the faint of heart.
 
If you need help with this routine, then shoot me a DM or comment down below!
 
All the best and I’m rooting for you,
 
Mattis Rogers

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I learned maps at single-digit age in East Tennessee and fell in love. Local, national, world, topo, road, political, all kinds of maps. I can’t remember when I learned where Indiana, Iran and Indonesia are, but it was long before I met people from there as a New York suburban teenager.
 
A hundred years ago geography and penmanship were important subjects in American schools. My schooling came after mid-century, and neglected them. So, I never had good handwriting, but geography didn’t have to be a school subject for me to love studying it.

I learned maps at single-digit age in East Tennessee and fell in love. Local, national, world, topo, road, political, all kinds of maps. I can’t remember when I learned where Indiana, Iran and Indonesia are, but it was long before I met people from there as a New York suburban teenager.
 
A hundred years ago geography and penmanship were important subjects in American schools. My schooling came after mid-century, and neglected them. So, I never had good handwriting, but geography didn’t have to be a school subject for me to love studying it.
 
Nowadays I spend my time with bikers and Wikipedians. All those people know geography and many of them know a few places that I don’t.

title: Can I do a mixed workout every day in the gym?
article:
Go at a different time.
Be flexible with what you're doing (this requires more knowledge of working out). 
Ask to work in. 
Number 2 is my personal favorite. 
 
If someone is on a flat bench press, I might do incline. If the benches are taken, I'll look for cable presses or flye machines. If those are taken, I might do dips or pushups. 
 
By doing this, not only do I get my workout in faster, but I'll also be forced to mix up my routine and enact muscle confusion without even trying. 
 
That's how I turn a negative into a positive.

title: What is your favorite sandwich ingredient?
article:
The number one is
Mortadella di Bologna! Possiblly cool in a slice of lukewarm genoese Focaccia. The only other ingredient, not necessary, but useful, could be just some salted pistachio cream.
Silver medal goes to Testa in Cassetta (head pudding)
A rich Rosetta or Biova as bread. Eventually a (very scarce, ) dose of Dijon mustard that’s the only other ingredient I could use into it.
 
Bronze medal to a great classic,
 
Roast beel and salsa tonnata (A tuna/caper/anchovy enrichened Mayo)
I would avoid Aregula (I hate it) and I should use just a lettuce leaf.

title: What is a good workout routine at home?
article:
The best home workout program is one you develop yourself. Get inspired and create something that works for you.
 
For me, resistance bands and two adjustable dumbbells are enough to shape my body.
 
Besides working out at home twice a week, I meditate; I use my bike regularly to commute to work and back and go out in the forest for fresh air at the weekend. I would never exchange this program for anything in the world.
 
I don’t want to impress anyone but myself. I want to have an aesthetic body but not at the expense of my health.
 
Use your creativity and you will be happy you did.

title: What is a good weekly workout?
article:
I'm going to assume you are referring to a full body, strength training workout. As a general rule, start with the largest muscle groups and work your way to the smaller. This is so you will be training the most taxing muscle groups when you are freshest. Also, if you train biceps before back for example, your arms will be too fatigued to properly work your much larger back muscles. Larger to smaller. So a full body workout will be arranged like this:
 
Legs
 
Back
 
Chest
 
Shoulders
 
Triceps
 
Biceps
 
Core
 
Calves
 
Hope this helps.

However, it's important to remember that the affordability of internet access can still vary widely depending on the country, region, and individual circumstances. While the cost of internet access has decreased in many places, there are still individuals who may face economic barriers to using the internet.

Continue Reading
Internet access has become more affordable and accessible in many parts of the world, including in regions with lower income levels. However, it's important to remember that the affordability of internet access can still vary widely depending on the country, region, and individual circumstances. While the cost of internet access has decreased in many places, there are still individuals who may face economic barriers to using the internet.
 
Additionally, even with affordable internet access, economic disparities persist, and poverty can affect people's access to various resources, including the ability to own or maintain devices like computers and smartphones, which are essential for accessing the internet. In some cases, people may have limited access to the internet due to economic constraints.
 
Therefore, it's entirely possible to find individuals from diverse economic backgrounds on platforms like Quora. People's participation on the internet is not solely determined by the cost of access; other factors like education, language proficiency, and awareness of online platforms also play a role in shaping internet usage patterns.
 
Quora, like other online platforms, aims to be a space where people from various backgrounds and experiences can ask questions, share knowledge, and engage in discussions, fostering a sense of inclusivity and diversity. It's important to recognize and respect the diversity of users and their unique circumstances when participating in online communities.

title: How workout exercises?
article:
For that last fuckin’ time…
 
Working your abs will NOT burn fat!
 
Successful, long-term fat loss is entirely down to your nutrition.
 
You can eat what you want, when you want to but you must stop eating as soon as your body tells you…”I’m satisfied.”
 
When you can do that (and you side-step emotional overeating), you’re going to lose weight and fat effortlessly. Without hunger. Without the dreaded yo-yo effect.
 
Stop looking for the “magic X”.
 
With X being supplement, exercise, diet, guru…whatever.

title: Who was the most ignorant American you have ever met?
article:
I was walking across the Millennium Bridge in London a few years ago. Two American ladies, both quite old, asked me to take a photo of them with St Paul’s Cathedral in the background. I did so happily. One of them then told me that she thought it was “good that they had modelled that building on our US Capitol”. I stifled laughter and told her that the dome of St Paul’s Cathedral was around 150–200 years older than the dome of the US Capitol. I wasn’t sure of the exact dates myself. (Both buildings are older than their domes.) The lady actually laughed at me and said “Oh please!” 🤣 “Ma’am,” I 
Continue Reading
I was walking across the Millennium Bridge in London a few years ago. Two American ladies, both quite old, asked me to take a photo of them with St Paul’s Cathedral in the background. I did so happily. One of them then told me that she thought it was “good that they had modelled that building on our US Capitol”. I stifled laughter and told her that the dome of St Paul’s Cathedral was around 150–200 years older than the dome of the US Capitol. I wasn’t sure of the exact dates myself. (Both buildings are older than their domes.) The lady actually laughed at me and said “Oh please!” 🤣 “Ma’am,” I said, “I think the US Capitol dome is really quite new. I mean, in Europe it would barely be regarded as historic.” I offered to look the dates up on my phone for her, but she stormed off with her friend, calling me a moron. It was difficult to work out why she had left her country! Those dates were 1710 and 1866, by the way.
